DIV1.P: Mr. Foxcroft's DISCOURSE Preparatory to the Choice Of a Minister.

A DISCOURSE PREPARATORY To the Choice of a Minister. Being the Substance of two Sermons preach'd to the Old or First gather'd Church in Boston, June 11. 1727. The Lord's day before their Election of a Colleague-Pastor.
By Thomas Foxcroft, A. M. Pastor of the said CHURCH.

Q.P: And now I say unto you, — If this Counsel, or this Work be of Men, it will come to nought. But if it be of GOD, ye can∣not overthrow it.

DIV1.P: BOSTON, N. E. Printed by GAMALIEL ROGERS in long Lane, for SAMUEL GERRISH at the lower end of Cornhill. 1727.

BODY.HEAD: A DISCOURSE Preparatory To the Choice of a Minister.

Q.P: And they prayed, and said, Thou Lord, which knowest the Hearts of all Men, shew whether of these — Thou hast chosen; that he may take part of this Ministry —.

DIV1.P: THE special Occasion that turn'd my Thoughts to this singular Text, must be obvious to every one, acquainted with the present Situation of Affairs in this Flock: And to such, it's presum'd, I need make no Apology for being on so peculiar a Subject to day.

The Consideration of this historical Passage might be introduc'd by some Remarks on the Context and
Story it belongs to. But all I shall observe, is only this; That there being a Vacancy in the College of the Apostles, and several Candidates (called the one Joseph, or Barsabas; the other Matthias) being singled out by the Church and nominated for that important Post, they refer'd it to the Determination of Heaven, by the sacred method of a Lot, which of them should be the Man to fill up that superior Station. An Expositor on the place observes, Mr. Henry. They were both such worthy Men, and so well qualify'd, that none cou'd tell which of them was fittest, but all agreed it must be one of them: Yet they did not propose themselves, nor strive for the place, but humbly sat still, and were appointed to it. The Church having chosen out and set up these as Candidates, they carry'd the matter to the Throne of Grace, spreading the Case before the Lord in Prayer, and then unanimously appealing to Him by a Lot for Determination. The Sum of the Prayer upon this great Occasion, we have on Record in the Text, — They prayed and said, Thou Lord who knowest the hearts of all Men, shew whether of those two thou hast chosen; that he may take part of this Ministry.
I shall discourse to the Words, under these Ob∣servations.
1. When some one is needed to fill up a Vacan∣cy in the Ministry, it shou'd be the Care & Desire of all concerned, That the LORD JESUS CHRIST wou'd shew whom He hath chosen.
2. Application shou'd be made to Him by earnest Prayer in this important Case.
3. CHRIST is to be consider'd by us at all times and in all matters, but especially in the present Case, as the Lord, who knows the Hearts of all Men.

Finally, I might observe, from the Interest the Eleven Apostles had in the Appointment of one to fill up their Number, & the Pattern they have left of a just Concern and Forwardness before, and Satis∣faction after the Choice; That it is a very desirable thing to a faithful Minister to have an agreeable Colleague, to be a Partner and Fellow-helper with him in his Charge: And that he will be dispos'd glad∣ly to receive such an one as a Brother, whom the Lord sheweth he has chosen. — But I shall dismiss this last Remark with barely mentioning it, and only insist on the three former.

DOCT. I. When some one is needed to be put into the Ministry, and fill up a Vacancy in this Ecclesi∣astical Order, it shou'd be the Care and Desire of all concern'd, That the LORD JESUS CHRIST wou'd shew whom HE hath chosen.

P.HI: THOU Lord, shew whether of these thou hast chosen.

DIV1.P: The Person immediately addressed to was most probably the LORD JESUS CHRIST, who is Lord of all, and Head of the Church; whose Prerogative it was to make Apostles, and who had before his Ascension personally chosen and appointed the Eleven.

The Ministry intended in our Text, was more especially the Apostleship; which is therefore added in the Text, — This Ministry and Apostleship. — It hints to us this just and useful Thought, (which in∣deed might have been mention'd first as a distinct Doctrine) That every Office in the Church of CHRIST is a Ministry; the Apostleship it self was so. Even CHRIST the Son of GOD, came to minister: And
shall the Servant be above his Lord? The Apostle says to Christians, We preach JESUS CHRIST the LORD, and our selves your Servants for JESUS sake. And if the Apostles, who were extraordinary Men of God, stiled their Work a Ministry; much more may the Pastoral Office be so called, which is in its Nature ordinary, and in dignity inferior to the Apostolate.

The Ministry is a common Name, which takes in all Offices in the Church, ordinary and extraordina∣ry, higher or lower. It is particularly very often apply'd to ordinary Pastors and Teachers; and is grown by Custom very much their special Character and Denomination. They are set in the Church for the work of the Ministry: They are called to minis∣ter about holy things; are separated to the Ministry of the Word; appointed to minister the Gospel of Salvation. Their Office indeed, as it is a Ministry, relates more directly and properly to CHRIST, their only Lord and Master. However, in a Sense, they are Servants of the Church; as Magistrates are Ser∣vants of the Commonwealth, or as Angels are called ministring Spirits, sent forth to minister unto the Heirs of Salvation. Yet suffer me to observe, they are not so the Church's Servants, as to be oblig'd only to obey their Orders, and execute their Votes and Decrees. But are call'd Guides and Overseers of the Flock, and said to have the Rule over them. Not that they have Dominion your Faith, or Power to tyrannise over Conscience, by human Im∣positions, as Lords over God's Heritage; but are de∣sign'd to be Ensamples to the Flock, and Helpers of your Joy, by assisting your Walk in the Faith and Order of the Gospel: and shou'd desire only by ma∣nifestation of the Truth, and humble Exercises of the Power which CHRIST has given them for Edification,
and not for Destruction, to commend themselves to every Man's Conscience in the sight of GOD.

IT is only a Ministerial and Stewardly Power, that is vested in them; to be regulated in all its Operations, by the sacred Rules and Instructions given in the Word of CHRIST. N. B. The greatest part of what is premis'd here, was for brevity omitted in the Pulpit; tho' its thought fit to insert it in the Print. From hence they must learn how they ought to behave themselves in the house of GOD, and to govern their respective Charges; expecting no other Subjection and Obedience, from their People, than what it is the Will of CHRIST his Churches shou'd render to such as have the Over∣sight of them. Altho' they shou'd take Care not to betray the Authority of the Eldership; but be just to their Commission, true to their Master, and speak boldly in his name, according to his Word, teaching and warning every man, and as there is occasion, re∣buking some sharply: Yet they must take heed on the other hand, they don't make unjust Encroach∣ments on the Privileges of the Fraternity, but allow them their full Power of Consent and Liberty of Judgment, in Church-Administrations; in things proper taking their Concurrence, and ever using the utmost Care to give no offence in any thing, that the Ministry be not blamed. In particular they shou'd beware of an uncondescending Spirit, an unhappy Stiffness of Opinion, and resolute Opposition to the Brethren, in Cases of lesser Importance, where (what∣ever is pretended) Humour will seem to govern them, more than Conscience. It's true that by the Constitution of these Churches a considerable Power is lodg'd in the Elders, insomuch that it seems they can put a Negative (for weighty Reasons) upon any Vote of the Fraternity, whether concerning Admissions,
Dismissions, Censures, or the like. For so runs the last Paragraph in the tenth Chapter of our Platform of Church-Discipline; The ordinary Power of Government belonging only to the Elders, and the Power of Privilege remaining with the Bro∣therhood, — It followeth, that in an organick Church, By an organick Church, is meant (as our Synod in 62 have defin'd it, under Quest. II.) A particular Congregation of visible Saints in Gospel-Order, furnished with a Presbytery, at least with a teach∣ing Elder, and walking together in Truth and Peace. and right Administration, all Church-Acts proceed after the manner of a mixt Admi∣nistration, so as NO Church-Act CAN be con∣summated or perfected without the Consent of Both. — By which it appears, that as according to our Principles, the Elders are not to exercise Church-Power, but by the Consent of the Brethren; So neither is there any Church-Act in ordinary cases valid without the Sanction of the Eldership: And indeed the Platform says, in so many words, That what the Churches are to act and do in these mat∣ters, they are to do in a way of Obedience — to the Direction — of the Elders. Heb. 13.17. Obey them that have the Rule over you, and submit your selves &c. Further, the eighth Paragraph is express, Nor may they oppose and contradict the Judgment or Sentence of the Elders, without sufficient and weighty Cause; because such Practices are mani∣festly contrary unto Order and Government, and Inlets of Disturbances, and tend to Confusion. And, as our famous Mr. Cotton (one of the Fathers of New-England, and first Teacher of this Church) has expounded our Platform in his celebrated Book of the Keys; the Power and Influence of the Pres∣bytery, both in the Church and in Synods or Coun∣cils, seems to me carry'd up to a greater Height con∣siderably,
than is either usually practised by Elders, or in fact allowed by the Brethren. However, it behoves them, as Ministers of the meek and lowly JESUS, as much as possible, to deny themselves; to deny their own Opinions, and Wills, and Rights, and stoop to the Infirmities of Men, and submit to Things difficult enough to be borne, in many cases; upon the excellent Principles and Views that acted the first Ministers of CHRIST, (2 Thess. 3.9.) Not because we have not Power, but to make our selves an Ensample unto you to follow us. — So 1 Cor. 9.12. We have not used this Power, but suffer all things, lest we should hinder the Gospel of Christ. And 2 Cor. 6. In all things approving our selves as the Ministers of GOD, in much Patience, in Afflictions, in Necessities, in Tumults, under Honour and Dishonour, evil Report and good Report &c. — They are not indeed to be the Servants of Men, so as tamely and servilely to prostitute their Authority to popular Humours, or Traditions of Fathers: Yet they must let their Moderation be known to all Men, while they faith∣fully execute the Commission they have receiv'd from CHRIST; and labour to be Examples of Meekness, Prudence and Condescention; becoming all things to all Men; pleasing them for their Good to Edifi∣cation; not seeking their own Profit, but the Profit of Many, that they may be saved; watching for Souls, as those that must give an Account, and con∣sider they are Stewards of the Mysteries of GOD.
But I proceed to observe as a further Preliminary. This Ministerial Trust is peculiar to a distinct Order of Men, instituted by CHRIST and of standing Use and Obligation.

The Ministry was originally appointed by CHRIST; and design'd, not for the Apostolick Age only, but to continue in the Church throughout all Ages; as
might be argu'd, in that the Reasons of the Institution are of a moral nature, and perpetual continuance; and also from those Scriptures, which tell us, That CHRIST has set Pastors and Teachers in his Church for the Work of the Ministry, till we all come to a perfect Man; — That in the Lord's-Supper (the Administration of which is their peculiar Province) CHRIST's Death must shewed forth until He come a∣gain; — And that He has left a Promise to be with his Ministers (teaching and baptising in his name) to the End of the World &c.

And it is an Office peculiar to a distinct Order of Men. 'Tis a sacred Inclosure, & do's not lie in Com∣mon, for every one that pleases, to invade and oc∣cupy. All publick and special Offices in the State are limited to particular Subjects: So is the Ministry of the Gospel. This Honour no Man taketh to him∣self, but he that is called of GOD. A liberty of pro∣phesying, as held by some, appears to me but an unlawful Licence, and tends to unhappy Consequen∣ces. The LORD is a GOD of Order, and not the Author of Confusion, but of Peace: and wou'd have all things done decently and in order, in all the Churches of the Saints. 'Tis said indeed, Covet to prophesy, and forbid not to speak with Tongues: If a Man be inspir'd with miraculous Gifts, let him speak. But otherwise let him be orderly call'd and separated to the Work. In ordinary Cases, a regular Election and solemn Investiture into the Office are requir'd to the Exercise of it: So that without these Praerequi∣sites, even the preaching of the Word in a public and stated manner (without design or desire of engaging in the Ministry, when call'd to Office) and much more the Administration of Sacraments, must be look'd upon as no small Irregularities. Not that the Power (strictly speaking) comes by Election, or Or∣dination
of Men, but by a Charter or Commission from CHRIST open'd in the Gospel: Yet those human Actions are generally necessary to the orderly exercise of Ministerial Authority. A Power, and the Right to exercise that Power, are two things very distin∣guishable: The former usually deriv'd by Commissi∣on from some superior Authority; but the latter by a solemn Investiture, done in many cases by Equals or Inferiors. 'Tis the Charter of a City or Laws of a Coun∣try, that appoints all Offices, and their several Pow∣ers and Businesses: Yet that alone do's not intitle any individual Person to this or that Office, one more than another. But there is something further requir'd to put any into Place, and authorise their assuming and exercising public Trusts. Thus, in some cases, there must be a particular Commission from the Government, and in others Election by the People: And in all cases there's usually a solemn Oath admi∣nister'd to the Party chosen or appointed, which is a necessary introductive to the authentic performance of his Office. A Counsellour elect, tho' approv'd by the Chair, sits not at the Board, till he has accepted the Place, and taken the Oath of Fidelity. A Justice, or other civil Officer, can't use his Power, till he's sworn in solemn Form. The Commission or Election indi∣gitates the Persons to whom the Law or Charter gives this or that Power: But it's his taking the Oath appointed, that properly invests him in his Office, or introduces him into the public Exercise of it.

Even so, in the present case, The Power of a Gos∣pel-Minister originates and is founded intirely in the Institution of such an Order of Persons, which our Lord was pleas'd to make, and has reveal'd in the Gospel: Where He states their Duty, limits their Authority, and fixes their proper Character; which it is not left to the uncertain Humours of Men to vary
from, add to, or diminish. So that to institute new Offices in the Church, or alter Offices divinely insti∣tuted, by increasing or lessening their proper Powers, Qualifications, and Employments, is nothing short of a bold Usurpation of CHRIST's Prerogative, and a rude Reflection upon his governing Wisdom, Good∣ness and Fidelity.

Yet the Institution requires some things preparato∣ry to the Exercise of the Office: And in ordinary cases (whatever may be allow'd for cases of Neces∣sity, which seem to carry a sufficient Warrant in themselves) it must be held contrary to Gospel-Or∣der, for any to exercise the Pastoral Power (or any branch of the Ministerial Office, except as Candidates or Probationers, occasionally) until solemnly invested with that Authority, and separated to that Work: Which is partly done by Election of the Church, and Laying on of the Hands of the Presbytery, and part∣ly by a voluntary devout Self-consecration.

Now (to come to the Business before us) when the Appointment and Investiture of some one into the ministerial Office is propos'd by a People, it shou'd be the Care and Desire of all concern'd, That the LORD JESUS CHRIST would shew whom HE hath chosen.

In speaking to this point, several Things may be briefly attempted. As (1.) to consider who is intend∣ed by the Person whom CHRIST has chosen. (2.) To inquire how or in what ways He doth shew whom he has chosen. (3.) To give the Reasons why it shou'd be the Care and Desire of a People, that CHRIST would shew whom He hath chosen.
I. I am to consider Who is meant by the Person whom CHIRST has chosen.
And here,
1. It means in general one whom He approves as sutably qualify'd for the Ministry, and in particular the Person whom He judges fittest for this place and people, and will own and bless.

When we read of the Fast, which GOD hath cho∣sen, it means such an one as He desires, approves of, and takes pleasure in. When we read of the chosen Men of Israel, it means the Choicest of their Tribes, the mightiest and best Men they had. So a chosen Generation, means an excellent Generation, the Lord's peculiar Treasure, a Generation of his Praise. — Mo∣ses his Chosen, is Moses his Beloved, in whom is an excellent Spirit, and in whom is his Delight. When we read Mat. 22.14. Many are called, but few are chosen; it may be expounded by ver. 8. They which were bidden, were not worthy. So 1 Pet. 2.6. Behold, I lay in Zion a chief Corner-stone, Elect, Precious:—(ver. 5.) Disallowed indeed of Men, but Chosen of GOD, and precious. — A Man approved of GOD among you, Acts 2.22. — The Apostle means the same thing by those different phrases, Rom. 16.10 & 13. Apelles ap∣proved in CHRIST; — Rufus chosen in the Lord.

So in our Text, by him whom CHRIST has chosen, we are to understand One that he approves of, as qualify'd for the Ministry, and has in special fitted for this Place and Station, and will accept, own, and bless therein. 1 Thess. 2.4. We were allowed of GOD, to be put in trust with the Gospel. Acts 9.15. He is a chosen Vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gen∣tiles, and Kings, and the Children of Israel. John 13.18. I speak not of you all; I know whom I have chosen.
(2.) It means the particular Person whom the Lord has decreed and appointed to this Post and Ser∣vice.

There are many Persons sutably accomplish'd for the Ministry, that Christ never designs to employ in this Work: And among the Candidates for a particular Station in the Ministry, there may be a Number suf∣ficiently fitted, and almost equally agreeable to a Peo∣ple; yet One only is design'd for it by our Lord, and his Counsel shall stand.
Shew whether of these Thou hast chosen, means in part, Shew which Thou hast appointed and sepa∣rated, in thy secret Counsels, unto this Ministry.

The Word of the LORD assures us, that Men are predestinated according to the Purpose of Him, who worketh all things after the counsel of his own Will. And as He hath chosen us before the foundation of the World, unto the Adoption of Children, accord∣ing to the good pleasure of his Will: So He has pre∣destinated some of us unto special Offices in his Church, and in particular unto the Ministry of his Gospel, to the praise of the glory of his Grace. Hence that of the Apostle, Gal. 1.15. Who separated me, from my Mo∣ther's Womb. — Which may be explain'd by that to the Prophet, Jer. 1.5. Before I formed thee in the Belly, I knew thee; and before thou camest forth out of the Womb, I sanctified thee (or separated thee to an holy use) and I ordained thee a Prophet unto the Nations.

It is from the beginning predetermined Who shall serve the Lord CHRIST in the work of the Gospel, and where he will employ them, in this or that part of his Vineyard. He hath determined the Times before appointed, and the bounds of their Habitation. If the Gospel of the Circumcision be committed unto Peter, and the Gospel of the Uncircumcision unto Paul, it's the Lord's doing; and herein he doth but perform the thing that was appointed for them.
I pass now in the next place,
II. To consider How or by what Means the Lord Je∣sus Christ doth shew whom He has chosen.
And here it may be observed; He shews this sometimes in extraordinary ways, and sometimes by more ordinary means.
I. He has sometimes shewn it in an extraordinary manner, by an immediate Call.

Thus, Aaron was made a Priest by the express Designation of GOD himself. Samuel and the Pro∣phets in old time, were call'd in uncommon ways, by heavenly Visions and Inspirations. — So the Apostles under the Gospel-Dispensation. Our LORD in the days of his flesh, personally nominated his first Minis∣ters, and orally shew'd whom he had chosen. See Mark 3.13, 14. — Again, When he rose from the Dead, he renew'd his Commission to the Apostles, and after his Ascension confirm'd their Call in an extra∣ordinary manner, when they receiv'd Power from on high, as we read Acts 3. — So He appear'd to Saul in a miraculous Vision, to make him a Minister, and call'd him by a Voice from the excellent glory; as in Acts 26.13 —

And besides the Apostles, many in the Apostolic Age, receiv'd immediate Calls to the Ministry; among whom were inspired Prophets and Evangelists. And perhaps oftentimes the Humane Call and the Divine Call, both met in one. It shou'd seem, Timothy and Barnabas were Instances of this. See Acts 13.2. and 1 Tim. 4.14.

But we are not now-a-days to look for extraordina∣ry Calls: besure not such as are neither of Men, nor by Men. If any pretend to an immediate Mission from Heaven, let them confirm their Pretences, by evident Miracles and Prophecies; or we can't think they come with sufficient Credentials.
2. The LORD usually shews whom He hath chosen in more ordinary ways, by a mediate Call.
He shews it by the voice of his Providence and Spirit, in more common methods of discovery.
Under the old Testament, Men were instated in the Priesthood by a Law of carnal Generation. GOD appointed the Posterity of Aaron to this Office, and the Succession went by natural Birth.

But now under the Gospel we have nothing to do with a Lineal Succession. This Method is abolish'd, and the Church of GOD left at their Liberty to de∣termine the Persons that shall be in Office among them. They are not confin'd to one particular Tribe or Family; but may chuse out of all the People.

Here I shall say distinctly, (1.) The Matter is usu∣ally to be referr'd to a voluntary Election by Vote, or Human Agreement. Yet (2.) in some cases, it may be determin'd by the special medium of a Divine Lot.

1. The Matter is usually refer'd to voluntary Elec∣tion, and Determination by VOTE: And when so, there must be such a Concurrence of Circumstances, as to render the Call plain and clear, if we would know whom CHRIST has chosen.

I might premise here, It is a principle professed among us, that the Churches of CHRIST have in the present case a power of Election; the Liberty to vote for their own Officers. In defence of which it's urg'd that the very Apostles wou'd not appoint so much Deacons, to serve Tables, without the express Suffrage of the People. (See Acts 6. begin.) And it's argu'd, from Acts 14.23. Where we are told, They ordained them Elders in every Church; That the Disciples were allow'd the same Liberty and Privilege in the Choice of their Pastors: The original word for ordained, sig∣nifying in its first political use, to design or constitute any Person an Officer by common Consent, which was usually express'd by lifting up the hand. The
word is but once more used in the New Testa∣ment, 2 Cor. 8.19. where it plainly signifies Elec∣tion to an Employment. — Speaking of some very worthy and famous Minister, the Apostle says, Who was chosen of the Churches to travel with us. But not to dwell upon this Argument; it is undis∣puted, that even in the Choice of an Apostle, to fill up the Twelve, the Disciples (being in number about 120 met together in one Body) were allow'd to come so near as to appoint the Candidates; any two from among themselves, whom they judg'd meetest for the place; and then they (together with the Apostles present) having first pray'd, gave forth their Lots for the particular Person. And the Lot falling on Matthias, he was numbred with the Eleven Apos∣tles, i. e. according to the Etymology of the greek word, was reckon'd among them by common Suf∣frage, receiv'd as an Apostle with universal Appro∣bation. — These things laid together are, I think, Authority sufficient, for the practice of the Churches, in chusing their own Officers: Which Ecclesiastical Li∣berty has been defended by some of our Divines, also from acknowledg'd Principles of natural Reason and common Equity, from the undoubted Rights and Customs of all free Societies, from the Nature of in∣stituted Churches, and the Ends of Order and Office-Power, as well as from primitive PracticeSee Dr. I. Mather's, Order of the Gospel, page 69. And Dr. Owen's True Nature of a Gospel-Church, page 62, &c.. But We have no Leisure at present to recite what is said on these several heads.

All I have further to do here, is to limit and qua∣lify the method in common use among us: And wou'd say, In order to a discovery of the Mind of CHRIST, or knowing whom the LORD has chosen, a People must see to it that their Election he regulat∣ed
according to his revealed Will, and the Call plain and clear, fair and orderly.
Now to this End,
First, Some things are requir'd on the part of the Electing Body or Fraternity.

For Instance, This must be rightly constituted; con∣sisting of Persons duly qualify'd to act in the affair. They that chuse must be rightful Members of the Church of CHRIST. This is made necessary, by our Scheme of Church-Order, to qualify Persons to vote in chusing a Minister: And for it, we have the Countenance of Scripture, particularly in the famous Example before us. They that appointed the Two, as Candidates for the Choice in our Text, were all Dis∣ciples: By which Name the Body of Believers in that day were commonly call'd, in distinction from the Twelve. The Two were chosen, as the Seven are said to be, by the multitude of the Disciples. And we are told how many were present at the Choice of Matthias:— The number of the Names were about an hundred and twenty: who are describ'd as Men which had associated with the Apostles, all the time that the Lord JESUS went in and out among them. They were open and known Disciples of CHRIST, who had confessed Him before the World, and communicated in the special Ordinances of his Kingdom. They are represented afterwards (together with others ad∣ded to them) as continuing in the Apostles Doctrine and Fellowship, and in breaking of Bread—. It seems they were all in full Communion, and approv'd Chris∣tians: Not any Persons among them, of a scandalous Character, or an incomplete Profession.

Now, from this leading Example, it's thought, we may learn who are proper Subjects of the Liberty and Power of Election in the Cafe before us; Name∣ly, the avow'd Members of a Gospel-Church, stated∣ly associating therewith in all public Worship and
Ordinances. — And indeed it's judg'd scarce ratio∣nal, that any shou'd be admitted to vote in a Com∣munity, or confederate Body, of which they are not orderly and confessed Members. Hence if there be any such distinct Society as a congregational Church, instituted in Scripture, it's thought a Principle found∣ed in Reason and the Nature of things, That none but approv'd Members of this particular Body, have a just Right to vote in their Ecclesiastical Affairs, especially in a case of such peculiar Con∣cern and Importance to the Peace, Purity, and Wel∣fare of the Church, as that of chusing a Pastor to watch over their Souls, and break the Bread of Life to them. It's pleaded by our Divines, that if we ex∣tend the Privilege beyond those Limits, we shall not easily know where to stop: Whether in respect of the Persons who must be admitted to this Privilege, or of other Privileges that such Persons may as reasonably lay Claim to. And it is observed, That some of the main Arguments for stretching this Liberty further (and in particular, that of contributing to the Mi∣nister's Maintenance) will if pursu'd in their ge∣nuine Consequences, carry the thing to a Length, that few, even of them who dislike the Limi∣tation among us, will care to have it brought to. Now it's a known Maxim, That Argument that proves too much, proves e'en nothing to the purpose.
To proceed,

Another thing is, The Church must see to it, that there be a due Examination and Trial had of the Candidates for Office among them. It is expresly requir'd in the case of a Deacon, that the Person be first proved (try'd and approbated) then let him use the Office. (1 Tim. 3.10.) Now surely it's of great∣er Consequence, that Elders and Teachers pass under a proper Trial: & this not only with regard to their gene∣ral Qualifications for the Ministry, but especially as
to their Fitness and Accommodation unto this Church and Place in particular. It seems reasonable that Christians shou'd judge for themselves, in this case. And who ordinarily are like to pass a better Judgment than the Church concern'd? They that were able in the Apostles day to look out among themselves, for the Deacons Office, Men of honest Re∣port, full of the holy Ghost, and of Wisdom, seem to me sufficiently capable of judging upon the Meetness of Persons for the Pastoral Care also. And are they not in many Places of Scripture expresly directed and ex∣horted to try the Spirits, whether they are of GOD; to beware of false Prophets, that come to them in Sheeps clothing, but inwardly are ravening Wolves, whom they shou'd know by their fruits; and if any Man preach any other Gospel unto them, than they have re∣ceiv'd, to hold him accursed. If there come any unto you, and bring not this Doctrine (saith the Apostle) receive him not into your house, neither bid him GOD speed. It's observable, the Bereans are com∣mended for trying of Paul and Silas's Doctrine by the Scriptures. And the Church of Ephesus is com∣mended for trying them which said they were Apostles. These Scriptures (together with the Reason of the thing) appear to me a sufficient foundation for the common Custom among us of a popular Trial of Candidates. And if besides the usual Probation by public Preaching (which is more subject to Mistakes) there were also private inquiries, especially by per∣sonal Conference, it might be of great Use and Be∣nefit: Though this kind of Exploration seems to be∣long more particularly to the Presbytery of the Church, if there be any such before instated. Agree∣ably the New-England Platform assigns it to the El∣ders, as their special Province, saying Chap. X. Sect. 9. It belongs
unto the Elders to examine any Officers, before they be receiv'd of the Church. — Which seems highly reasonable, particularly for that by our Con∣stitution, the Elders of the Church are to transact the Business of Ordination, and officially or authori∣tatively install Persons into the Offices they are cho∣sen to. It's one Resolve, or Rule stated, Platf. Chap. IX. Sect. 3. In such Churches where there are Elders, Imposition of Hands in Ordination is to be perform'd by those Elders. — Hence They are eminently concern'd in that Apostolic Charge, 1 Tim. 5.22. Lay hands suddenly on no man. — It is meet therefore Chap. VIII. Sect. 3. be∣fore any be ordained or chosen Officers, they should first be tried and proved: And that the Eldership already subsisting in the Church, should not have any Colleague obtruded or impos'd upon them at least, while they have any rational grounds of Dissatisfaction. For as the Prophet speaks, Can two walk together, except they be agreed? — It is observable, the Vote and Lot in the Designati∣on of Matthias were manag'd in the Presence and under the Conduct of the Apostles. And so was the Election of the Deacons: as you may see in the Sto∣ry. From whence some infer, that there is a Power of Inspection and Guidance in the Choice of Officers (as well as in the Admission of Members) which be∣longs to the Elders; if there be any praeexisting in the Church. But whether this be a standing Right of the Eldership, or whether they have no more than the Liberty of common Suffrage, I list not to dispute. And upon another head, Our venerable Fathers have left us their concurrent Opinion, saying, Sect. 8. We judge it much conducing to the Well-being and Communion of the Churches, that where it may conveniently be done, Neighbor-Churches be ad∣vised
withal, and their Help made use of in the Trial of Church-Officers, in order to their Choice. Upon which One See the late Rev. Mr. Symmer's Life, page 63. has well observed to this Purpose; "The Communion of Churches and Interest of Re∣ligion depend very much (humanely speaking) on the Unity and good Agreement of the Elders in the Vicinity. If they love one another, and agree well together, they will strengthen one ano∣ther in their Work: But if they disagree, this will tend to weaken their Hands, and discourage their Hearts more than a little. "Churches therefore ought, what in them lies, to suit their Neighbor∣ing Ministers and Churches, in the Choice of a Minister: Remembring they are not only to chuse an Officer for themselves, but a Neighbour for Them.

And certainly then it is adviseable that the Congre∣gation (as we distinguish) or Body of Noncommu∣nicants (being baptis'd Professors, associating con∣stantly in the Word and Prayer, with the Church concern'd) shou'd have some Regard shewn to them in this Affair; surely at least, as much as is due to any Christian Neighbours. And a great deal of Pru∣dence is generally necessary here, to consult their Peace and Satisfaction, while the Church's Right of Election (or Precedence in the Choice) is asserted and exercised.

But however these things be, surely a Trial ought to be made, by one means or other, sufficient for the Church more immediately concern'd, to form a ma∣ture Judgment upon; that there may be no place for Jude's Complaint, There are certain Men (false Teach∣ers) crept in unawares. It behoves them to take Counsel together, for imparting Light to one another, in a way free from all Party-Designs and Artifices;
to proceed with a just Deliberation, and in the whole Affair to act with Caution, Prudence and Impartiality. They must especially ask Counsel at the Throne of Grace, by devout and fervent Prayer; as we have an Example in our Text.

And the Result must be a general Union of Hearts in a free and voluntary Choice, made without any Collusion or Constraint; without all deceitful or vio∣lent Measures, to flatter or force on a Vote for anyHistories inform (as one observes) That in ancient Times the Choosers of Overseers (or Pastors) gave with their Voice solemn Asseveration or Oath, that their Choice was wholly free, and not the fruit of undue Influence.. A willing Concurrence of the Majority of the Church is necessary, by all the Rules of Society, to a deter∣mining Vote: And the more of Unanimity, the clearer Discovery is made of CHRIST's Mind and Will; especially when Persons of Eminence and Dis∣tinction (for their Gifts and Graces, rather than worldly Abilities) are concurring in the Choice.

Secondly, There are some things requir'd on the part of the Candidates in view, to make them capable Subjects of an Election. There are certain Qualifi∣cations, indispensably necessary to this End, to be respected by the Chusers.
Thus, the Sex must be regarded; according to those Apostolic Canons, which we have in 1 Cor. 14.34, 35. And 1 Tim. 2.11, 12.

Again, The Age must have some Regard paid to it. Under the Levitical Law, they were allow'd to perform Service in the Tabernacle, only from thirty years and upwards, until fifty years old: Though in David's time Persons were admitted Probationers at twenty, and as it shou'd seem stood so for ten years. However, this is no Rule now under the Gospel, and
I know of no Reason for Persons waiting now till they are thirty years old, before they enter upon the Ministry, any more than that they shou'd be discharg'd at fifty, as in Jewish days. Yet that ancient Consti∣tution seems to carry so much of Morality and Rea∣son with it, that it appears highly proper, decent and expedient, that atleast Persons be come to years, to Men's Estate, before they be chosen into the Ministry.—But I shall not enlarge here; having already given my Sentiments on this head in a Sermon Serm. at Mr. Lowel's Ordination, page 30 &c. which some of you have in your hands.

And then a Man's moral Character, and intellectu∣al Furniture, as well as Orthodoxy must be respected. He must be a Person of known Integrity, Capacity, and Fitness. Not only a Man of sufficient Learning, but one apt to teach, and holding fast the faithful Word; One of unblemish'd Morals and exemplary Piety; One of a meek, humble, and Self-denying Spirit, and indu'd with a good degree of Prudence and Discreti∣on, to take Care of the Church of GOD, and secure its Peace and Purity, while he contends earnestly for the Faith, and diligently attends the practical Concerns of Government, Order and Discipline. According to that Apostolical Directory, 1 Tim. 3. And Tit. 1. Which Chapters I commend to serious Consideration at your leisure.

In a word, He ought to be a Person, not only of good Life, and good Abilities, but of a Ministerial Genius; regularly inclin'd; dispos'd to the Work, upon proper Motives, Desiring the Office of a Bishop, as the Apostle hints, 1 Tim. 3.1. Indeed a Man may covet the Office, and not be at all qualify'd (as they, 1 Tim. 1.7.) In which case, an Election to Office is ipso facto null and void; being the choice of an incapable Subject. By previous Qualifications for
the Ministry, a general Designation of the Persons to be called to it, is made by CHRIST himself: But where this is wholly wanting (says One Dr. Owen.) it is not in the Power of any Church under Heaven, by virtue of any outward Order or Act, to com∣municate Pastoral or Ministerial Power unto any Person whatever. So on the other hand, Persons may have a competent portion of Ministerial Gifts; and yet being habitually averse to the Work, and resolutely engag'd for some other Employment, or dispos'd to this only for worldly Ends, if these things be known, it can't be proper to chuse any such: And in either case the Call is not clear. Something like the Spirit of the old Prophets, to whom the Word of the LORD, came and was in their Hearts as a burn∣ing Fire, begetting an ardent Thirst after the Glory of GOD, and good of Souls, is one considerable step towards a Divine Call. Some inward Sense of this seems necessary to make a Man's Call clear to him∣self: And a rational Apprehension of it in the Peo∣ple seems necessary to legitimate their Election. For as the LORD looketh on the Heart: So must we, as far as it is discoverable; though still we must beware of uncharitable evil Surmisings. But if a Man plain∣ly discovers a strong Bent to any civil or secular Employment, it is unadvised to make Choice of such an one for the Ministry. Or if he visibly discovers the prevailing grounds of his Inclination to the Mi∣nistry, to be grossly carnal and worldly (as Eli's Pos∣terity, 1 Sam. 2.36.) can a People safely, or even lawfully, chuse such an one? I may add, if one in general sincerely inclin'd, is invited to this or that particular Station in the Ministry, and cannot find a Heart (even after serious Inquiry and humble Prayer) to comply, I see not that the Call of any
People is of such force and obligation, as that he must sin in refusing of it. We find, in a case of some∣what the like nature, even Apostolical Invitations and Intreaties, were in vain with Apollos: See 1 Cor. 16.12. It is requisite then that a Man have a well-principl'd Disposedness to the Ministry, and to the particular Place where he's invited.

And when there is thus a Sufficiency of Gifts and Qualifications, and a sutable Inclination in the Can∣didate, concurring with an unanimous or general Agreement of a Christian People (both Fraternity and Presbytery) in the Election and Approbation of him; especially if also there be the Concurrence of Neighbour-Elders & Churches; here's such an assem∣blage or conjunction of happy Circumstances, as ren∣ders the Call strong and valid, and seems clearly to point out the Person whom CHRIST has chosen. In ordinary cases, the regular Vote of a Church (en∣forc'd by such a general Desire and Agreement on all sides) is look'd upon as the Voice of GOD, by which He calls Men forth to Service in his Church. The good Shepherd so called, may well be said to enter in by the Door.
But yet,

2. In some special Cases, it shou'd seem proper to refer the Matter to a LOT, for Determination; and if this be done in a regular and solemn manner, the Issue may justly be look'd upon as a manifestation of the Will and Mind of CHRIST.

I shall a little particularly insist on this too, because I am so naturally led to it by the Context, which tells us that this was the Method in which CHRIST shew'd He had chosen and appointed Matthias to be an Apostle.

As to the Nature of a Lot, I shall only say, The Word may be sometimes used in a lax, and less pro∣per
Sense, for any kind of Reference made to GOD, though in a way that implies the Contrivance and Activity of Men, and requires only a Divine Influ∣ence to direct their Thoughts and Powers, in order to the Event. In which sense the Vote of any Body of Men, may be call'd a Lot. But yet strictly speak∣ing, the Lot is an awful Appeal to Heaven, in such a way and manner as shuts out human Counsel and Influence, and depends on a special Agency of Di∣vine Providence, for the actual determining of an Event. Prov. 16.33. The Lot is cast into the Lap; but the whole Disposing thereof is of the LORD. The Judg∣ment's the LORD's. "The Event, though casual to Men, is directed and determin'd by GOD's Counsel and Providence", which controuls and governs in all Cases.

The Lot was an Ordinance of GOD much in Use under the Jewish Dispensation, for Decision of Right in uncertain cases, and putting an Issue to weighty Matters depending, which were not with facility de∣terminable in any other way. Thus the Land of Ca∣naan was divided to the several Tribes by Lot. (Numb. 26.55, 56.) The Scape-goat was chosen by Lot. (Lev. 16.7.) The Lot was made use of, in de∣tecting of secret Criminals: as in the case of Achan (Josh. 7.16.) And of Jonah (Jon. 1.7.) And of Jonathan (1 Sam. 14.42.) The Method of a Lot was taken to determine the Time, when each Family should bring in their Quota of Wood for the Service of the Temple, after the Jews Return from their Captivity: And who of the People shou'd go up out of the Villages and Cities of Judah, to dwell at Jeru∣salem, where the Rulers resided, and the House of GOD was in building, and where they wou'd be most expos'd to the Malice and Envy of their Ad∣versaries: It's said, The People cast Lots, to bring one of Ten, to dwell there. (Neh. 10.34. & 11.1.)

In a word, this Method was us'd in the Election of Persons to Office; as in the case of Saul chosen King of Israel. (1 Sam. 10.19 —) So of the Priests and Leontes, whom King David distributed in∣to many distinct Companies or Courses (as well as the Militia of the Kingdom.) They cast Lots for every Post and Service, as well the small as the great, ac∣cording to the house of their Fathers; as you have the Account at large in 1 Chron. 24th Chapter and onwards. —

And it's remarkable, the first Election of any Per∣son into Office in the Christian Church (wherein there was any thing of the ordinary Acting or Influ∣ence of Men) viz. that which our Text relates to, was consummated or perfected by a Lot. Indeed there was a previous Nomination of Two, by Suffrage or Vote of the whole Multitude: But the Determi∣nation of the particular Person (whether of these two) they for very good Reasons put upon a different Is∣sue, and appealed to Heaven by a solemn Lot.

As to the Manner of this Lot, we are left at an uncertainty: Though some tell us Vid. Whirby in loc. "They put two Lots into two Urns, or Ballot-boxes; the one con∣taining the two Names of Joseph and Matthias, the other the Name of an Apostle, and a Blank or void Lot; and then drawing forth the Name of Joseph out of one Urn, and the void Lot out of t' her, they knew that the Lot remaining with the Name of an Apostle upon it, belong'd to Matthias.

As to the Reasons or special Grounds of their cast∣ing the Lot in this case, neither are we particularly inform'd of them. Whether there was any thing in the Nature of the Office, the Person was to be ap∣pointed to; as some are of Opinion, who say, the ultimate Determination of the individual Person, and
immediate Disposition of him into his Office, by GOD, was necessary to give him Apostolical Authority: or whether it was done upon no other than the com∣mon moral Reasons, which influenced in the cases above-mention'd, in old Testament-times; I shall not enter into any Debate.
The late excellent Mr. Henry Vid. Expos. 1 Chro. 24. seems to have been of the Judgment, that the Lot in these cases was pre∣sidential.
So the memorable Mr. Baxter, whose Words up∣on the place Vid. Paraphr. are; I know no Reason why the— Pastors of the Church (at least in cases of doubt) shou'd not now be so chosen, i. e. by Lot.

What the Judgment and Practice of Antiquity was, I have not had Leisure particularly to inform my self. Only I'll give you a Passage out of The Order of the Gospel (by the late venerable Dr. Mather) where he has the following words: Nothing is more evident than that in the first Ages of the Church, Pastors were chosen by all and on∣ly their Flocks: In chusing a Minister, they did Clerozein, that is, Chuse him by Lot; from whence it was that Ministers had the Name of Clergy given to themPage 69..
All I would say upon the Lot in the present Case, give me Leave to offer in the following Hints. And allow me the freedom of young Elihu, in saying Hearken to me, I also will shew my Opinion.

As to the Lawfulness of a Lot, for determining in this Case, if under a just Regulation, I presume no one will dispute it, that doth allow of the practice in civil Cases. "And it is hardly imaginable that GOD shou'd not have left that lawful, which is so evidently necessary to the Peace and Security of Mankind, and which
the unavoidable Condition of human Affairs makes of such great and eminent Use to the World."

And now for the Expediency of it in Cases sacred, particularly in the present Case, under some spe∣cial Circumstances, which frequently happen, I sup∣pose much might be easily said, and strongly argu'd.

In general, it is a Case of no little Importance; such as will bear us out in applying so awful a Me∣thod for Determination. The Lot is a thing holy and reverend: and to use it in a ludicrous or wanton manner, about Trifles, and Matters of small moment, is a Folly in Israel, judg'd to be no less than taking the Name of the LORD in vain. But the case before us is of vast weight and solemn consideration: such as calls for the most serious Treatment from Men; and wherein, if in any matter at all (the Honour of CHRIST being so nearly concern'd in it) we may hope that the Lord will own and accept the Appeal made to Him, and give an answer of Peace.

Moreover, It's often a doubtful Case, and attended with no small degree of Uncertainty. Many times the case is like that in the Story of our Text: Se∣veral Candidates present, who are very worthy and desirable for their Accomplishments, and so recom∣mend themselves by their public Performances, as well as private Conversation, that a People are will∣ing it shou'd be either of them, and agree it shall be one, or at least suppose it will, and yet scarce know where (many of them) to pitch their ultimate Choice. Now in doubtful cases, what more proper method for Determination than a religious Lot? Indeed in things already determin'd by a clear Revelation of the Mind of CHRIST in holy Scripture, or very appa∣rent to human Reason, and capable of being easily determin'd by a little serious and impartial Conside∣ration; here there's no occasion for such an extraor∣dinary
method: And if there be no occasion, it will be judg'd but profane trifling with the Name of CHRIST, to appeal to him by a Lot.—But where there is real Uncertainty, and sober Doubt, or a Variety of Apprehensions among the Parties concern'd in an important Case (important whether in regard of its Nature, or its Consequences) and there be little Pro∣bability of a peaceable Issue by any other means; then cast the Lot, for a Resolution of the Doubt.

In fine, the case before us is many times attend∣ed with a great deal of Difficulty; and the divid∣ed Sentiments among a People do too often, for want of some happy means of Accommodation, at last throw them into great Contentions and Disorders.

Among a number of Candidates, there's generally seen a Diversity of Gifts and Talents: And hence, a∣mong a People, as there is a variety of Tastes and Judgments, so in consequence hereof, there's usually a difference of Choice and Inclination; one being determin'd for this, and another for that —. And now as Men are commonly very much dispos'd to be fond of their own Opinion or Fancy; so this by a natural efficacy makes them the more wedded in their Affections, and resolv'd in their Choice; that they can't tell how to brook a Disappointment. Hence they are too often put upon sinister Methods to ob∣tain their Ends: or if balk'd of their Expectations, are carry'd into inordinate Resentments and conten∣tious Measures. Such is the remaining Infirmity in the best and wisest of Men, and such the Subtilty and Power of our grand Adversary the Devil (who goes about, as a roaring Lion, to devour and to dis∣turb) That through the just Judgment and Permissi∣on of Providence, the Peace of the Churches is oft-times miserably broken, in pursuit of unreasonable Prejudices on the one hand, or of a fond Opinion and extravagant Affection on the other; while they
have Men's Persons in Admiration, so as to be puffed up for one against another. And in no case hardly are a People more apt to fall into carnal Contention, than in that before us. Scarce any thing makes so much Noise, and occasions (for the time) so much sinful Anger and Evil-speakingSymmos's Life p. 57.. Even Paul and Barnabas, those eminent Saints and Ser∣vants of CHRIST, differ'd about a Companion and Fel∣low-labourer in the Ministry: And the sacred His∣torian tells us Act. 15.39. The Contention was so sharp between them, that they parted one from the other, and each took his Colleague. So of the Church at Corinth, we have the Apostle giving that doleful Account, 1 Cor. 1.11 — It hath been declared unto me of you, my Brethren, that there are Contentions among you. Now this I say, that every one of you saith, I am of Paul, and I of Apol∣lo, and I of Cephas &c. Again, Chap. 3.3, 4. For whereas there is among you Envying, and Strife, and Divisions; are ye not carnal, and walk according to Men? For while one saith, I am of Paul, and another, I am of Apollo, are ye not carnal? — And in our Days, O! how much is there of this Carnality to be seen among Professors; this spirit of party and facti∣on, the leven of malice and wickedness! How often have Churches been almost rent to pieces by scan∣dalous Quarrels about the Settlement of a Minister; to the great Dishonour of Religion, to the Reproach of our Profession, and to the Gratification of them that malign our Ecclesiastical Constitution, and envy us our happy Rights and Privileges! For want of a wise Conduct, popular Votes and Choices are too often attended with ungodly Strifes and Emulations. Now as the Apostle observes, Where Envying and Strife prevail, there is Confusion and every evil work. And then such Divisions are difficult to be heal'd.
We may apply here that of Solomon, — A Brother offended, is harder to be won than a sirong City, and their Contentions are like the Bars of a Castle. Hence then in this critical case it greatly behoves a People to study for Quietness, to follow the Things that make for Peace; and if it be possible, manage so as to secure this. The beginning of Strife, is as when one letteth out Water: When it has got some little Vent, it will it self widen the Breach, and in a little time grow irresistible, if speedy care be not taken to put a stop to it. Therefore says the wise Man, leave off Contention before it be meddled with.

Now, what more effectual Method to this End, (that is, to leave off Contention before it be meddled with) can be us'd, in the present case, than that of a religious Lot? The Lot, every one that has any thing in him serious, looks upon as sacred and vene∣rable. The very Pagans yous find in the case of Jo∣nah, paying a profound Reverence to the Lot, as carrying in it something peculiarly Divine. Here GOD is beheld as sitting in Judgment: And the Awe of this will have the strongest Influence, of any Reflection in the World, to restrain Men's turbu∣lent Passions, and suppress those fretful Resentments that so frequently break out upon a Disappointment, when we eye only the hand of Men in it. The less there is of Man, and the more of GOD is seen, in any affair, the greater Content shall we take in the Issue. — What was I that I shou'd withstand GOD! — Lest haply ye be found even to fight against GOD!

The Apostle observes, An Oath for Confirmation, is to Men an End of all Strife. And agreeable is that Remark of Solomon, Prov. 18.18. The Lot caus∣eth Contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty. Here the Wise Man hints the right application of the Lot, viz. In difficult and doubtful Cases, to pre∣vent or end Contentions. By telling us what is
done, he tells us what ought to be done, in such Cases. Then a Lot is lawfully us'd, when it ei∣ther preserveth or procureth Peace and EquityDod & Cl. in loc.. And as to the Efficacy of this Method, you have not only the Wise Man's Testimony, but the concurrent Suffrage of common Reason, and universal Expe∣rience.

Hence, upon such Views and Considerations as these, it seems a high Propriety (at least in some Cases) to take the Method of a Lot, in the Choice of a Minister: Which will make it more emphatically a Divine Choice, and have a happy Tendency to set∣tle the Minds of Men, and adjust all Disputes where there are contending Parties.
But then in this Method there are several Provi∣soes & Limitations to be carefully observ'd. Parti∣cularly,

1. It seems necessary that some certain Candidates be singled out, and nominated, by general Consent in a voluntary Vote: (For this you have the Ex∣ample of the Church who appointed Two, in order to the Lot for an Apostle) Which will effectually secure the privilege and liberty of the Body Ecclesi∣astic, to all good Intents and Purposes.

2. It is necessary that the Persons in view, be su∣tably qualify'd: — I do not say equally in all respects, but each of them in some agreeable measure. — For It must be a lawful and justifiable Case, in which the Lot is us'd. And therefore it must not be cast for any that are apparently incapable Subjects of Election: Because there is no uncertainty here. If either of the Persons propos'd are known to be dis∣qualify'd by any essential Defects, whether in point of Knowledge, Faith, or Morals; it is but a profane mocking and tempting of CHRIST, to draw the Lot:
and therefore unlawful to put the Matter to such an Issue. It is but as Haman's Lot for the chusing some lucky day to accomplish a wicked Design: Or as the Soldiers impious Lot for our SAVIOUR's seamless Coat (so fam'd for its miraculous Virtue) which cou'd give none of them a just Propriety.
3. The Lot must be employ'd in a solemn and re∣ligious manner.

Being a practical Appeal to Heaven, it's but fit the Matter shou'd be transacted in a serious frame, after a godly sort. The Lot is too awful a thing to be dally'd with. It must not be us'd rashly, and in a light and lusory way; but with Deliberation, Seri∣ousness, and Solemnity. And 'tis highly fitting this sacred Transaction shou'd be accompany'd with de∣vout Prayer; at least Ejaculatory, and in such Cases of Importance as that before us, with more solemn Sup∣plications. At the Division of the Land among the Children of Israel, it's observ'd, Joshua cast Lots for them in Shiloh, before the LordJosh. 18.10..

And now if the Lot be thus regulated, the Success may (I think) in Faith be committed to Divine Providence: And the Event may well be look'd up∣on as an incontestible Discovery of the Mind of CHRIST; shewing hereby whether of these He hath cho∣sen. I cou'd never yet see why in such a Case we mayn't now-a-days, as they did in old time, expect the special Interposition of Heaven, to give a perfect Lot: As King Saul pray'd to the LORD GOD of Israel, in the Case depending between Him and his Son on one side, and the People on the other1 Sam. 14.41..

Indeed the Religious Lot is grown much out of Custom; though the Civil be retain'd and in fre∣quent Use: yet the Divisory Lot, more than the
Elective. But why the Lot is so disus'd in matters spi∣ritual and ecclesiastical, I can at present think of no better or truer Reason than the common Abuses and Profanations of it in other cases. It is generally own'd, The Lot may lawfully be us'd about civil Concerns, where weighty Consequences are in prospect, and where unhappy Differences can't well be prevented or issu'd any other way. Yet even here, whatsoever is more than this, comes of Evil. The Lot is a virtu∣al Calling upon GOD the LORD, to direct and de∣termine us: And therefore to employ this religious Rite, in cases that are plain and clear, beyond all rational Dispute, or in frivolous, much more in sportive Matters, is by Divines judg'd unlawful, as making too bold with Providence. And the custo∣mary unhallow'd use of it in trivial Plays and Pas∣times (with the too unserious, and perhaps often un∣necessary Application of it in many Affairs of Life) appears to me the most obvious Reason why it is fallen into Disuse in sacred Things. 'Tis owing to the Subtilty and Influence of an Hellish Tempter, that the Lot is so desecrated and perverted, in a sen∣sual sportful World. As one observes; GOD hath his Ordinances: the Devil has his. GOD hath Sacraments for his People: the Devil has his. Is the Oath GOD's Ordinance? In Affront to this, the Devil set up profane Swearing, to les∣sen the Authority and Veneration of a sacred Oath. So is the Lot GOD's Ordinance? Herein also the Enemy sows his Tares: and to affront GOD in this Ordinance of his, he has his gaming and sportive Lotteries. That there may be no Religion in the use of Lots [and that the Lot mayn't be apply'd to the Service of Religion] the Devil has turn'd them all into Play and Di∣version, or a method of Gain and Profit, or into Su∣perstition, Bible-Lottery (as it is call'd) and Sorcery
or Divination. However, the frequent Abuse and Misapplication of a thing, capable of being directed to so excellent purposes, as the Lot is, doth not at all forbid the regular Improvement of it: And I can't see why it mayn't be as safely and profitably em∣ploy'd in sacred Cases (where it seems indeed the most proper and needful) now as ever. Nor can I see why the Lot shou'd be laid aside, on the Account of vulgar Abuses, any more than the Oath; which though as much prostituted and as often violated, is notwithstanding made use of still, without any Scruple, and with good Success, as an End of Strife.

You may observe, I go very much on rational Grounds; and build not upon Scripture only: Tho' if this directs to a Lot, in any Case, I think it is sufficient Authority, were there no such evident Grounds in Reason for it. But I have enlarg'd here, on a too uncultivated Subject, much further than was at first intended. I shut up this head with that free Address of Elihu to his worthy Fathers, the three Friends of Job; — Hear, O ye wise Men, and give Ear, ye that have Knowledge. For the Ear trieth Words, as the Mouth tasteth Meat. Let us chuse to us Judgment: let us know among our selves what is good.
I hasten now to the last thing under the Doctrine, which is —
III. To say Why it ought to be the Care and De∣sire of a People, in the Case before us, that CHRIST wou'd shew whom He hath chosen.
And here I shall only hint,

In the first place, It's but fit and reasonable, that He shou'd have the Chusing of his own Servants; and is desirable that Such shou'd be put into the Ministry, whom he approves, and will own and bless.

He is the Fountain of all Power: and may lodge it in whose hands he pleaseth. He has instituted the several Offices in the Church: And 'tis his Pro∣vince, as Head and Lord, to fill them with his Ser∣vants; whom, and in what way he pleaseth.

As the Ordinances must be only such as are of his Institution: So the Dispensers of them must be such as are of his Designation; else they can't expect his Presence to be with them. The LORD once complain'd of some Prophets, That they ran, and He did not send them: Of whom He declares (which is threatning enough) That therefore they should not profit the People at all, Jer. 23.21, 32. It is a dreadful thing to sit under the Preaching and Administrations of a Man, whom we can't see CHRIST bearing Testimony to, by a special Blessing on his Labours, or any visible Tokens of his spiritual Pre∣sence with him.

Hence it's a very reasonable Care, when a People are concern'd and desirous, that CHRIST wou'd shew whom He has chosen. It's fit his Will shou'd be done, his Counsel take place; and to be desir'd that his good Pleasure may be known.

Again, Consider, CHRIST is infinitely Wise, and a∣ble to make the best Choice for a People. We may imagine him looking upon them, and saying (as in Jer. 49.19.) Who is a chosen Man that I may ap∣point over them? For who is like Me? — Who's like Me, for chusing the fittest Instruments, and spiriting them for their Work? — We may allude to Rev. 17.14. He is LORD of Lords; and they that are with Him, are called, and chosen, and faithful. As He will accept none but such as are of his own Ap∣pointment: So He perfectly foreknows whom He will own and bless. Job. 13.18. I know whom I have chosen. Hence He said to Ananias concerning Saul, against whom that Disciple had entertained very
great (and once just) Prejudices, as you read, Acts 9.13 &c. Ananias objected, Lord, I have heard by many of this Man, how much Evil he hath done &c. But the Lord said unto him, Go thy way; for he is a chosen Vessel unto me to bear my Name before the Gen∣tiles. We may be apt to throw aside this or t'other, as a despised Lamp; when to the LORD he may be a Chosen Vessel. We shou'd gladly therefore refer it to his Wisdom, to determine for us; and be sollici∣tous that he wou'd shew whom He has chosen. Thus we shall put Honour on his wise and sovereign Providence.

In a word, Thus we shall consult our own Interest and Peace. For a People will be more dispos'd to re∣ceive Such in the Lord with all gladness, and hold them in Reputation, whom they see CHRIST shewing He hath chosen. Whatever Objections Ananias had against Saul; yet when he heard those Words, He is a chosen Vessel unto me, the good Man instantly embrac'd him as a Brother, with great Affection. And this will have a natural and (by the Divine Blessing) a powerful Tendency to a People's profit∣ing by the Ministry of such an one. — And then this will afford no small Consolation to the People of GOD, as it is to them an evident Token of Salvation; a happy sign of the Lord's Presence with them; that his Spirit remains among them, and that his King∣dom shall be still upheld in the midst of them. Ezek. 34.29, 30. I will raise up for them a Plant of Renown. Thus shall they know, that I the LORD their GOD am with them; and that they, even the house of Israel, are my People, saith the LORD GOD.

For these and other Reasons, it shou'd be the Care and Concern of a People, who have before them the Choice of a Minister; That the LORD wou'd shew whom He hath chosen, whom he hath appointed, and will approve. This was the Sollicitude and De∣sire
of the Church and the Apostles, in the Case our Text refers to; and this Record was made of it for the Admonition of all Posterity. For whatsoever things were written aforetime, were written for our learning and ensample.

DIV1.HEAD: The Afternoon-SERMON.

Q.P: And they prayed, and said, Thou Lord, which knowest the Hearts of all Men, shew whether of these — Thou hast chosen; that he may take part of this Ministry —.

DIV1.P: THE Subject we were upon in the Morning was, That when some one is wanted to supply a Vacancy in the Ministry, it shou'd be the sollicitous Desire of all concern'd, That the LORD JESUS CHRIST wou'd shew whom He hath chosen.
I come now to another Observation from the Words, viz.

DOCT. II. In the important Affair of calling a Mi∣nister, Application shou'd be made to the LORD JESUS CHRIST, by fervent Prayer, expressing the Concern and Desire of our Souls, that He wou'd shew whom He hath chosen.
So in our Text, They prayed and said —
Prayer is a devout offering up of our regular Desires to the Throne of Grace. It shou'd not only be our Hearts Desire, but our Prayer also, That CHRIST wou'd shew us whom He hath chosen.
Here we might observe,

The LORD JESUS CHRIST (the Son of GOD) is together with the FATHER and HOLY GHOST, the pro∣per Object of religious Worship. He has all those Divine Perfections, and sustains all those Divine Re∣lations, Titles and Characters, which proclaim him the worthy Object of our Faith, Love, Prayer and Praise, in their most exalted Sense, and highest Ex∣ercises. And to Him should our Prayers sometimes be immediately directed; if we wou'd honour the SON, even as we honour the FATHER. The Protomartyr Stephen in his dying moments pray'd to the Lord JESUS. And in our Text, we have the Apostles and an Assembly of the first Disciples, uniting their solemn Supplications to Him. — The Title, LORD, is the special Title of CHRIST; his constant Style, throughout the New Testament. And it was customa∣ry among the primitive Christians to make their reli∣gious Addresses unto Him; insomuch that they were characteris'd, and distinguish'd from Jews and Hea∣then, by their Calling upon the Name of the LORD JESUSAct. 9.14. Rom. 10.12. 1 Cor. 1.2..

There are some special Cases, wherein it seems pe∣culiarly proper and congruous, distinctly to invocate the LORD JESUS CHRIST. Thus, particularly in the Administration of the LORD's Supper, which is of his Institution, and bears his Name, and the primary De∣sign whereof is to do honour to his Memory, by a grateful Celebration of his redeeming Love. So in the Election (as well as in the Ordination) of Per∣sons,
to serve CHRIST in the Ministry, it seems equal∣ly proper, that the Name of the LORD JESUS shou'd be expresly and immediately call'd upon.

Now, if you ask What is to be requested of Him, in such a Case; I answer in general, as in our Text, That He would shew whom He hath chosen: — (Imply∣ing) That he wou'd chuse for us in great Mercy, and that he wou'd discover his Mind and Will to us, in those ways in which it may be expected: That he wou'd preside and govern in the Choice propos'd by us; influence our Views and Resolutions, and cause a Coincidence of all things to the accomplish∣ment of his own Counsel), and bringing the Affair to a happy Result: That all matters of Controversy be∣tween Him and us may be remov'd, and no Obstruc∣tions lie in the way to hinder a Blessing from being bestow'd upon us: That when the Lot is cast into the Lap, there may be a gracious Disposal thereof, by his Power and Wisdom; that the Lot may fall upon One, who shall be a Pastor according to his Heart; One whom He hath called by his Grace, and will delight to bless and prosper. — This may be the Tenour and Scope of our Prayers on such an Occasion.
And if you ask Why we shou'd thus employ Pray∣er in the Case? I answer,

1. Our LORD himself has directed us to this Method. Besides that Prayer is the appointed way for obtain∣ing all the Benefits we desire. It's particularly pre∣scrib'd in the Case before us; 'Tis imply'd in that direction to the Disciples, Mat. 9.38. Pray ye the Lord of the Harvest, that He will send forth Labourers into his Harvest. — It is observable, the Apostle Paul frequently and pathetically desir'd the Prayers of this and the other Church whom he purpos'd to visit;
That he might come to them with Joy by the Will of GOD &c. (See Rom. 15.30 — 32. So Heb. 13.18, 19.) Which Directions will very well take in the present Case, by parity of Reason. Now this is Argument enough, in any Case: 'Tis the Wil of GOD in CHRIST JESUS concerning you.

2. The Example in our Text shou'd have it's influ∣ence upon us. They had their Eyes to the LORD for a Decision from his special Providence, and they lift∣ed up a Frayer: wherein they have left a good Copy for future Ages to imitate. The Apostle said (Phil. 3.17.) Ye have us for an Ensample. So (2 Thes. 3.7.) Your selves know how ye ought to follow us. And doubt∣less the sacred Historian put the Prayer in our Text on Record, to make the Apostles and primitive Church an Ensample unto us to follow them. As the bad Actions of Men are related in Scripture-Story, for our Admonition and Warning: So the good and laudable Actions of the Saints are story'd, not only for their Commendation, but for our Imita∣tion and Learning. Hence we are exhorted to be Followers of them who through faith and patience inhe∣rit the Promises. Heb. 6.12.
3. 'Tis a Case wherein we have special Declarations and Promises of CHRIST, to plead, and to animate our Faith, in Prayer on this Occasion.

'Tis a virtual Promise we have in Psal. 68.18. Thou hast ascended on high; — Thou hast received Gifts for Men; yea for the Rebellious also, that the Lord GOD might dwell among them. Which Gifts (as the Apostle expounds the Psalmist, Eph. 4.11.) par∣ticularly mean sutable Instruments for the Work of the Ministry. Such Gifts CHRIST has receiv'd, to be bestow'd on his Church and People, as the visible Signs and Means of his gracious Presence in the midst of them. This affords one advantageous Plea. And we may put in suit that precious Promise, Isai. 20.30.
Though the Lord give you the bread of Adversity — Yet thine Eyes shall see thy Teachers &c. Also that, Jer. 3.14, 15. Turn, O backsliding Children; for I am mar∣ried to you; — And I will give you Pastors according to mine heart, which shall feed you with knowledge and understanding. GOD expects that we in faith convert these Promises into Petitions and Pleas at the Throne of Grace. As you may learn from Ezek. 36.37. Where, after various Promises made, it is added, Thus saith the LORD; yet for this will I be enquired by the house of Israel to do it for them.
4. The Gift we receive in answer to Prayer, we may hope will prove a Blessing indeed, in which we shall rejoyce.

Usually, the Benefits we receive by Prayer, are doubly sweet and pleasant. 'Twas a most comforta∣ble Reflection to pious Hannah, For this Child I prayed. So when it may be reflected, For this Mi∣nister I pray'd, how great the Consolation! —When the LORD, by any satisfying Evidences, sheweth whom He has chosen, as it will afford peculiar En∣couragement to the Person to accept the Call: so it will by a natural efficacy help us to attend on the Ministry of such an one with a greater Faith and li∣velier Hope for a special Benediction of Heaven up∣on his Administrations and Labours among us. Such a Minister may humbly triumph, with the Apostle, as in Rom. 15.29. I am sure, that when I come unto you, I shall come in the fulness of the blessing of the Gospel of CHRIST. And a People so highly favoured, may make that the Song of their grateful Souls; Psal. 65.14. Praise waiteth for Thee, O GOD, in Sion: — Bles∣sed is the Man whom thou chusest, — we shall be satis∣fy'd with the Goodness of thy House. So Psal. 118.21, 26. I will praise the Lord, for thou hast heard me. — Bles∣sed is he that cometh in the Name of the Lord: We have blessed you out of the House of the Lord.
I shall only add, by way of Argument,

5. 'Tis a very concerning Case; in which it ex∣ceedingly behoves a People to chuse well, and is very awful to commit an Error. — It's but fit all Business of any moment shou'd be carry'd on with Prayer. How much more the very important Busi-of Calling a Minister! It's a great Affair of CHRIST's Kingdom, and important Concern of his Glory. — It is of vast Moment to our Souls, and has a near As∣pect on the best Interests of our dear Posterity. An Error here will be of dangerous Tendency, and extensive Influence. — And then 'tis a very critical Case; in which without CHRIST's special Direction and Leading, we shall certainly commit egregious Mistakes, and run into Confusions: shall be in danger of laying on Hands suddenly, and so of being partak∣ers of other Men's Sins. For (as one observes) Whoever have a sinful hand in the Choice of an unskilful and unfaithful Pastor, are so far guilty of all the Hurt he doth, and shall answer to GOD for the Blood of the Souls, which perish through his Mismanagement. Their Sin in this Case, maketh way for the Hireling; and so hath Influ∣ence upon all the Harm he doth. There shou'd be a holy Sollicitude then, lest we take any false Steps, or fall upon any wrong Measures, or come in∣to any unhappy Resolves: but that all be done to the Glory of GOD, and with the Security of the common Good.

Hence, it will be our Wisdom to put the Affair under our LORD's Conduct; and not lean to our own Understandings, nor trust in our own Hearts. Commit thy Works to the Lord: So shall thy thoughts be established. Make thy Prayer unto Him, and He will hear thee: Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be establish'd unto thee; and the light shall shine upon thy ways.
These Reflections afford very strong and moving Arguments for Prayer on the solemn Occasion before us.

But then, if we expect an Answer of Peace, we must see to it, that we offer the Prayer of Faith, and lift up holy Hands; without Wrath and Doubting. In many Cases, it may be said, Ye ask, and receive not, because ye ask amiss. Let us every one think with the Psalmist, If I regard Iniquity in my Heart, the Lord will not hear me. — Verily let not that Man, who is of a double heart, imagine that he shall receive any thing of the LORD. We must ask in Faith; embracing the Promises, and realizing CHRIST's Sufficiency and Faithfulness to perform them. — Yet we must ask humbly; sensible of our utter unworthi∣ness; confessing our Sins, and putting all our Ini∣quities from us. — In a word, we must pray fer∣vently, and with a holy Importunity, as those that know the Worth and Moment of the Gift we are asking of our ascended LORD. — Every one concern'd, shou'd wrestle for it in fervent Prayer by himself in secret. And every Family apart. And the Con∣gregation of the LORD; making Mention of it al∣ways in their common Prayers, & uniting in solemn ex∣traordinary Supplications (as they in our Text) on so weighty an Occasion.

It has been the laudable practice of these Church∣es, to have their Days of Fasting and public Prayer, when meditating the Choice of a Minister: Which Days, I wou'd observe, shou'd be kept seasonably (in general, the earlier the better) before the Thoughts and Resolves of a People are particularly fix'd and terminated.

Now, let us every one reflect a little on our Con∣duct in this Matter. Have we been thus employing Faith and Prayer, with regard to the Choice before us. 'Tis true, when we had our Church-Fast upon
upon Occasion of the Removal of our late worthy Pastor
The Rev. Mr. BENJAMIN WADSWORTH; who being chosen Presi∣dent of Harvard-College, and Application thereupon made by the Hon. and Rev. the Overseers, for the Church's Consent to part with him for that Service; the Church after humble Prayer, with serious Considera∣tion and previous Inquiry into his Mind upon this weighty Affair, voted a conditional Compliance; Resolving, That if he judg'd it his Duty to accept of the Call given him, We would humbly submit, and say, THE WILL OF THE LORD BE DONE! Which Vote was pass'd June 16. 1725. With a considerable degree of Unanimity, as it pleased the LORD then to dispose our Hearts; and with no small Appearances of a very solemn Awe upon every one's Spirit: together with the sensi∣ble workings of a just and great Affection to our faithful Pastor, and the visible Tokens of a special Divine Conduct and Influence; the appre∣hension of which, as it gave a general Satisfaction, so it was my Relief under the Anxieties of that critical Juncture; and in the Days of doubt∣ful Expectation which have since rolled over us, that Reflection has oft refreshed the Bowels of many; particularly by furnishing us with an Argument or Plea in Prayer, and encouraging our Hopes, That the LORD who had called his Servant from us, and who hath the Residue of the Spirit, wou'd lead and influence in the Choice of a Successor; to preserve Peace and Truth, and provide graciously for us —.
Not long after the President's Instalment, and actual going from us, the Church at an occasional Meeting, saw fit (among other things) unanimously to agree upon keeping a Day of Prayer, with a special View to the remarkable Change of Circumstances we were now come under. Upon this great Occasion Judging our selves called to extraordinary Prayer, It was therefore resolved (GOD willing) that we would speedily keep a day of Fasting together, to beg of GOD a sancti∣fied Use of so important a Dispensation; and that He wou'd teach us the way wherein we ought to go, and in his good Time provide for us another Pastor according to his own Heart. — The said Fast was on Aug. 17. following.
I have thought it not amiss, to gratify the Publick, by this particular Account of that Affair, and our proceedings upon it. from us unto another important Post, We did unitedly spread our Case before the LORD; and have at our occasional Meetings, as well as upon the LORD's day, from time to time been humbly moving our blessed SAVIOUR and Head to look upon in our present State and supply our Wants: But have we all likewise in our private Requests been conti∣nually
making mention of our Case, and begging Divine Appearances for us, with a suitable Concern and Fervour of Soul! Can our Closets and our Fami∣lies testify on our behalf, that we have been giving our selves to Prayer; beseiging the Throne of Grace day and night with our ardent Cries, and believing Intreaties, that the LORD wou'd shew us (among all the Candidates we have heard) whether of these He hath chosen? Or have we been contenting our selves with a few prayerless Thoughts and Endeavours? Have we not been cold and indifferent, and too un∣thinking? Or else all our Care and Zeal too inde∣vout, irreligious, and not accompany'd with a spirit of prayer and resignation to GOD?

Surely it is fit we examine into our Temper & Conduct here. This becomes us, as Men and as Christians. And then this is necessary for the better ordering our Expectations and Hopes. For if we have sought the LORD humbly and earnestly, we may look He will be found of us. Since he hath assur'd us, as in Mat. 18.19. Again I say unto you, that if two of you shall agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of my Father which is in hea∣ven. But if we have been casting off Fear and re∣straining Prayer, while we have pursu'd our several Aims and Desires; we may justly expect He will hide his Face from us, and cover our Paths with Darkness.
