Hence then (whatever our personal Managements and Dispositions have been) let us now stir up our selves to seek the Lord by importunate Prayer. Ye that make mention of his Name, call upon him in the Day-time, and in the Night, keep not Silence before Him. In∣treat his Favour with your whole Heart, and give Him no rest, until he shew whom He has chosen; until He restore the Smiles of his Face on his Sanctu∣ary, which is so far desolate, and set up a burning
and shining Light in this his Candlestick. Let the Prophet's Resolution be ours, Isai. 62.1. For Zion's sake will I not hold my peace, and for Jerusalem's sake I will not rest until the Righteousness thereof go forth as Brightness, and her Salvation as a Lamp that burn∣eth. — Thus we shall be prepar'd to receive the Bles∣sing from the LORD, and to give Him the Glory and the Praise.
But I hasten to the last Observation.

DOCT. III. CHRIST is at all times and in all Affairs, especially in the present important Case, to be con∣sidered by us as the LORD, who knoweth the hearts of all Men. — So in the Text, Thou LORD, which knowest the Hearts of all Men, shew whether of these Thou hast chosen.

Here I might (not unprofitably) go into the Proof of CHRIST's Dominion and Omniscience, that he is LORD, and that he doth know the hearts of all Men; and doctrinally treat upon the exalted Title and relative Perfection here ascrib'd to our blessed SAVIOUR; which indeed are none other than the in∣communicable Prerogatives of JEHOVAH; the high Glories and appropriate Characters of the Supreme and Infinite MindN. B. There were some distinct Enlargements upon these Heads in the Discourse given from the Pulpit, which are here left out, only for brevity sake to accommodate the Reader..

But it is the practical Improvement, to be made of these Reflections, which I mainly aim at. And they are very applicable, to regulate our Views, and go∣vern our Tempers and Deportments; as in all other Affairs, so particularly in the present Case. — Hence the Church in our Text, prayed, saying, Thou Lord, which knowest the hearts of all Men —. Doubtless it
was not without a special Direction of the HOLY GHOST, that they fixed on this particular Property, and this Tide of CHRIST, in their Invocation; where∣by were ministred unto them those pious Reflections, that probably had an excellent Influence into the whole Conduct of the Affair. And it may be of no small benefit to a People in the like Case, to make use of and apply these affecting Idea's of CHRIST.
I. A due consideration of CHRIST as the LORD, may be of very profitable Consequence, in the ma∣nagement of the Affair before us.
To give a few hints here distinctly.

1. This will teach us, from a Reverence to the Office of the Ministry, as the Institution of CHRIST our Glo∣rious LORD, to treat the Affair of chusing and calling a Person to that Office, with a becoming Seriousness and Solemnity.

Is CHRIST the LORD? We should then fear before him, and make Him our Dread. His Name is holy and reverend: And all that wears the stamp of his Authority, should appear venerable to us. The LORD's Day, the LORD's Supper, his Word, his Peo∣ple, should be call'd the Holy of the LORD, Honour∣able. So the LORD's Ministers should be highly es∣teemed in Love, and their Office held in Reputation by all such as wou'd honour JESUS CHRIST our LORD, both theirs and ours. For he has said to his Ministers, He that despiseth you, despiseth Me. — A reverent re∣gard to the Institution of CHRIST, shou'd teach us to treat all Affairs relating to the Ministry, and in par∣ticular to behave our selves in the important Work before us, with the greatest Gravity, with solemn Thought, a deep Awe, and religious Concern.
2. The serious Consideration of CHRIST as LORD, will help to regulate our Aims, and guide our Choice.

It will influence us to consult the Glory of our LORD; to do all in the Name of CHRIST, and study to manage so as to secure his Honour, and promote his Interest, I may allude to some of the Apostle's Words, and say, He that realises the Dominion of CHRIST, will care for the things that belong to the Lord, how he may please the Lord. In the electing of a Mi∣nister, that Consideration will terminate our Views on such a Person as we do deliberately and upon ra∣tional Grounds judge will be most acceptable to CHRIST, and most likely to be a special Instrument of his Praise: One that is not only capacitated by a due portion of Gifts and Powers, to serve the Interest and Kingdom of CHRIST; but whose Heart is (visi∣bly to us) set right with GOD, and bound for his Glory. It will tend to make this our governing Aim; and transport us above the corrupt Influence of carnal or sinister Regards, the unhappy Results of a vicious Self-Love.
3. It will point us to the Word of CHRIST, as our Rule, in fixing our Judgment, and conducting the whole Business before us.

It will lead us to consult the Scriptures for Direc∣tion, and to take Counsel from them, in managing this Affair of CHRIST's Kingdom. It will influence us to attend to the inspired Apostle, as if CHRIST the LORD spake to us, where he describes the Evangeli∣cal Bishop, and sets down Rules for chusing a good Minister of JESUS CHRIST.

And it will preserve in us a just Concern, through the intire process of the Affair, to demean our selves with a strict Conformity to the reveal'd Will of CHRIST; that we may carry it as becometh the Gospel, and walk worthy of the LORD, unto all pleasing.
4. It will direct us to go to CHRIST with our Pray∣ers, and our Thanksgivings, for Success.

It is a Motive to earnest Prayer, and will put each one upon applying to CHRIST, in that humble Lan∣guage, Acts 9.6. Lord, what wilt Thou have me to do? It directs and excites us to be looking unto JESUS who is the Author and Finisher of every hap∣py Settlement; and to be intreating his Favour, his Conduct, Assistance and Blessing. — Also it teaches us to be thankful to him for Prosperity in our Endea∣vours; to give him the Glory, if we succeed, who is LORD over all, and governs second Causes after his sovereign Pleasure. Hence that of Ezra, By the good hand of our GOD upon us, they brought us a Man of Understanding, a Minister for the house of our GOD, Ezra 8.18.
5. It may be improv'd to check all distrustful Fears, and encourage the Faith and Hope of a favourable Answer to our Prayers, and happy Result of our se∣rious Consultations and Endeavours.

A firm belief and due thought of CHRIST's Domi∣nion, as Head of the Church, will tend to lay a Restraint upon our impatient Fears, in a Day of Clouds and Darkness; to enliven and invi∣gorate our Hopes, in Cases of Difficulty, and in times of doubtful Expectation. If CHRIST sits at the Helm; if He be the supreme Moderator of all Events; we are sure then, Nothing shall come to pass but by his Permission, and with the Security of his own Inte∣rest and Glory. There are many Devices in the heart of Man: but the Counsel of the Lord, that shall stand. He sits upon the Floods, and rules the Waves of the Sea, and stilleth the Tumult of the People. He scattereth the Proud in the Imagination of their Hearts; but his Thoughts are very deep, and his Designs cannot be defeated. He is Head over all things to the Church: And if He love the Church, which is his Body, we may trust He will protect and keep it; will nourish and cherish, and make all
needful provision for it. We may be sure that all things shall be overrul'd for the promoting of Jeru∣salem's Peace and Welfair. Hence then in the pre∣sent Case, we shou'd establish our Thoughts, and confirm our Faith and Hope, by meditating on CHRIST's Power and Dominion. A realising View of this will help our Unbelief, strengthen our Hearts to wait upon the LORD; who is a GOD of Judgment, and blessed are all they that wait for him. Be patient therefore, Brethren, unto the appearing of the Lord: Behold, the Husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the Earth, and hath long Patience for it. Be ye also patient; stablish your hearts: Be not faithless but believing. Believe in the LORD your GOD, so shall ye prosper.
6. It will be of happy use, to promote in us a due Resignedness and Submission to his holy Will and Dispose.

Knowing that when the Lot is cast into Lap, the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord; This will teach us a willing Subjection to his Counsel and Pleasure. The Disciples having pray'd, as in our Text, pro∣ceeded to cast the Lot; and it falling on Matthias, 'tis observ'd, He was numbred with the Eleven Apostles; doubtless with great Peace and Harmony. And so much seems intimated in this Remark of the Histo∣rian; the original word for numbered, Calculis allectus. Beza. importing (as hinted before) his being counted among them by the united approbatory Suffrages of all concern'd. Barsabas and his Friends doubtless readily yielded to the Choice, and all unanimously receiv'd Matthias (though not the first in Nomination) as the Man whom CHRIST had chosen and prefer'd. We hear of no Murmurings or Exceptions.
Now a serious Consideration of CHRIST as LORD, will tend to assist us unto the like excellent frame and carriage, in the Affair before us.

Antecedent to the solemn Transaction, there shou'd be a humble referring the Conclusion to a Divine Dis∣pose; in that primitive Language, Acts 21.14. The Will of the LORD be done! The Consideration of CHRIST as LORD will promote this happy Resignation of Soul; and will help to save us from that ungodly Peremptoriness and Presumption in our Designs and Resolves, and that vain boasting in Creatures, which it should be our Care to avoid. According to that of the Apostle, James 4.15, 16. For that ye ought to say, If the Lord will, We shall — do this or that. But now ye rejoyce in your Boastings: all such rejoycing is evil. — 1 Cor. 3.21, 22. Let no man glory in Men: for all things are yours, whether Paul, or Apollo, or Cephas.

And so, when the Work is brought to a fair and orderly Issue, it is then our Duty to acquiesce in the Choice, and be satisfy'd wherever the Lot falls. Nei∣ther let us tempt CHRIST, nor murmur ye. Our Lan∣guage must be like that, of Hezekiah, 2 Kin. 20.19. Good is the Word of the Lord. Is it not good, if Peace and Truth be in my days?

Sutable Views of CHRIST's Dominion will tend to produce in us a Patient Submission to his Providence, if cross'd in our Desires, and disappointed of our Hopes: will make us willing to part with our dearest Enjoyments; to give up our fondest Expectations, at his bidding, and not pursue our Designs against the manifest Checks of Providence, as if we meant to step into the Throne of CHRIST, and correct the Measures of the most High.

It will dispose us to a chearful Reception and Christian Treatment of Him, as our Brother and Mi∣nister of GOD, whom we behold approved in CHRIST;
chosen in the LORD. Hence we read, Gal. 2.9. When James, Cephas and John who seemed to be pillars, perceived the Grace that was given unto Paul, they gave to him the right hands of Fellowship. And hence that Exhortation to the Church of Corinth, 1 Cor. 16.10, 11. Now if Timothy come, see that he may be with you without fear: for he worketh the work of the Lord, as I also do. Let no man therefore despise him.

And then it will by natural Consequence make us patient towards our Neighbours and Brethren, will restrain us from passionate Resentments and dividing Measures, under a Frustration of our Hopes, and ex∣cite us to do all things without Murmurings, Disputings or unreasonable Oppositions. Hence the Apostle makes use of the Name of the LORD JESUS, in per∣suading the Church at Corinth unto Peace and Union, when carnally contending, and divided into Parties, one saying, I am of Paul, and another I am of Apol∣lo: As in 1 Cor. 1.10. Now I beseech you, Brethren, BY THE NAME OF OUR LORD JESUS CHRIST, that ye all speak the same thing, and that there be no Divisions among you: but that ye be perfectly joined together in the same Mind and in the same Judgment. The Name of the LORD JESUS carries a sacred Charm with it, that tends to still all Contention, Clamour, and Dis∣pute among his Disciples (particularly in the present Case) and excite the greatest Care of Peace, Chari∣ty, and Unity, as that which makes very much for the Honour of CHRIST, and the Interest of his King∣dom. Hence those pathetical Expostulations & Coun∣sels of the Apostle, in Rom 14. Who art thou that judgest another Man's Servant? Or why dost thou set at nought thy Brother? — For he that in these things serveth CHRIST, is acceptable to GOD, and approved of Men. Let us therefore follow after the things which make for Peace, and things where with one may edify another.
But I pass now to say,
II. The Consideration of CHRIST, as knowing the Hearts of all Men, is another very useful Reflection, and may be of great Service in the present Affair.

This gives a very awful, and yet an equally joyful Idea of our Lord; and what He wou'd have solemnly consider'd by his People. Rev. 2.23. All the Churches shall know, that I am He which searcheth the Reins and Hearts. How else indeed shou'd He judge the Se∣crets of Men, and give to every one according to his Works; as He certainly will do! The Eyes of the Lord are in every place, beholding the Evil and the GoodPro. 15.2, 11.. Hell and Destruction are before the Lord: how much more then the Hearts of the Chil∣dren of Men? Verily to his piercing Eye every Bosom is transparent, and all things there appear in the most open Light to Him, which are beyond the Reach of all human Discovery. And this Thought is capable of an application to very good Purposes, both by way of Direction and Incentive; as in the common Con∣cerns of the Christian Life, so particularly in the extraordinary Affair before us.
To illustrate this, let me suggest a few particulars.
For Instance,

I. The Consideration of CHRIST's knowing the Hearts of all Men, as in our Text apply'd to the present Affair, may be useful to direct us in our Choice, what to aim at, and what regards to be influenced by.

It was a Reproof the Apostle gave to some in the Church of Corinth, who indulg'd such a spirit of E∣mulation about their Teachers (2 Cor. 10.7.) Do ye look on things after the outward appearance? This is a common Rule of judging: but a false Rule, at least a very imperfect and insufficient One. It shou'd
seem, that some boasted mighty things of themselves, and affected to make a fair Shew in the flesh, but they boasted of things without measure, and by fair Speeches deceived the Hearts of the Simple. We often suffer our Views only to glide upon the Super∣ficies of Men and Things, and take no pains to enter into their Realities and true Characters. We are either easily impos'd upon by deceiving Appearances, and draw up a hasty Judgment. Or else we are led away with Mistakes about the Nature of Things, and consider not where true Excellency lies. Agreeably, things of comparatively less Significancy, often have the preference with us: the things of the Body, to the things of the Soul: So again the things of the Mind, to the things of the Heart; intellectual Ac∣complishments, to spiritual Graces and moral Virtues: Which is the most perverse Judgment in the World. And to act under the Influence of such a false View of things in the Affair before us, must needs be of dangerous Tendency.

But here our Text may set us right; which intimates that the Disciples looked chiefly at the Heart, in the Choice before them; and that CHRIST looketh at the Hearts of Men, in chusing Pastors for his Church. We are apt to look chiefly at the Head, and external Appear∣ance, an happy Utterance, bright Gifts, the Powers of Reason, the Beauties of Language, or the like: but verily the Lord looketh at the Heart. The Lord weigheth the Spirits; and he estimates us by our inner Man. To be renew'd in the spirit of our Minds, after the Image of Him that created us in Righteousness and true Holiness, this is our high∣est Glory; and is the most exalted Character of a Minister of the Gospel: Whose Adorning, let it not be that outward Adorning of Eloquence, Beauty, or worldly Pomp: but let it be the hidden Man of the Heart, in that which is not corruptible, even the Or∣nament
of Humility and Sanctity, which is of great price in the sight of GOD. The Righteous is more excellent than his Neighbour. In a Minister, it's the Christian, we are to look at, more than the Scholar, or the Oratour. He shou'd indeed be apt to teach; able also to convince Gainsayers. And a People shou'd Covet earnestly the best Gifts: Yet shew I unto you a more excellent way: Seek a Proof of CHRIST speak∣ing in him, and being with him. For though one speak with the Tongues of Men and Angels, and have not Charity (a Principle of Divine Love reigning in his Soul, the Love of CHRIST constraining him) he is as a sounding Brass, or a tinkling Cymbal: And tho' he have the Gift of Prophecy, and understand all Mysteries, and be fill'd with all Knowledge; yet if he have not a true Love to CHRIST, and Love to Souls, prevailing in him, verily he is Nothing1 Cor. 12.31. & 13.1, 2.. That's a Divine Rule, for proportioning our Esteem of others, as well as of our selves; Rom. 12.3. To think so∣berly, according as GOD hath dealt to every man the measure of FAITH; in judging of which, a rational Charity must be our Guide and set the Limits.
2. The Consideration of CHRIST as knowing the Hearts of all Men may serve further to animate and encourage the Hope and Faith of his People in the pre∣sent Case.

It may serve to encourage Prayer on this occasion, and the Hope of a gracious Answer. Moses seems to have had it in View▪ when he pray'd, as in Numb. 27.16. Let the Lord, the GOD of the Spirits of all Flesh set a Man over the Congregation.—He formeth the Spirit of Man within him, and he pondereth the Spi∣rits of Men. He knows every one's particular Tem∣per, Capacity, and real Character, with unerring
exactness. He knows the Hearts of all Men; the Hearts of Ministers and People; of Candidates and Electors. —CHRIST knows the Wants of his People, and knows their Hearts Desire and Prayer; and as our Advocate with the Father, represents the same unto Him; which may assure us of obtaining our Requests, if agreeable to his Will. See Mat. 18.19, 20. So 1 Job. 5.14, 15.

He knows what is the Mind of the Spirit: whom the holy Ghost will make Overseers of the Flock; and so how to order his Mediatorial Intercession, in the present Case, according to the Will of GOD. (Rom. 8.27.)

He that searcheth the Hearts, knoweth who are the fittest to be chosen; who will be the most holy, humble, skilful, faithful, active Instruments of his Glory. Solomon observes, The fining pot is for Silver, and the furnace for Gold: but the Lord trieth the HeartsPro. 17.3.. He has a clear prospect into the secret Recesses of the Soul, and knoweth whose Heart is upright toward him, and who is most formed for his Praise. As to Men, they themselves scarce know what spirit they are of. Hence not he that commendeth him∣self, is approved; but whom the Lord commendeth2 Cor. 10.18.. And as for popular Applause, this is often founded in false Notion of Worth, or ignorance of Men's true Characters. Hence that of our LORD to the Pharisees in his day, who were so much had in ho∣nour among the People; (Luk. 16.15.) He said unto them, Ye are they which justify your selves before Men; but GOD knoweth your Hearts: for that which is high∣ly esteemed amongst Men, is Abomination in the sight of GOD.

I may allude to the Story 1 Sam. 16. of Samuel's viewing the Sons of Jesse (among whom GOD had provided
him a King to reign over Israel) and observe, We are ready to say of this and the other, Surely the Lord's Anointed is before him: But the Lord seeth not as Man seeth. We look upon Eliab, and are flush'd with Hopes, he is the Man; but the Lord saith, Look not on his Countenance, or on the Height of his Stature; for I have refused him. And when we look upon Abinadab, neither hath the Lord chosen him. And when Shammah is made to pass before us, Behold, neither hath the Lord chosen this. Yea, tho' we turn our Eyes to seven others, it yet appears The Lord has not chosen these. And when we are ready to inquire, with Samuel, — Are here all? It happens there remains still one, the most unthought of: and the Lord saith, Arise, anoint him; This is he. For Man looketh on the outward Appearance; but the Lord looketh on the Heart: And when He bestows in Mercy, and not in Wrath, He gives a David, a Man after His own Heart. — Indeed he was pleas'd to appoint a treacherous Judas to be one of his first Apostles: and He often permits a worldly Demas to be put into the Ministry. But then He has some wise and holy Designs of his Kingdom to serve by it: and it's sometimes done in Judgment to a People, that have provoked him to Anger. But when he has Intentions of Favour to a People, in whom he delighteth, he gives them a faithful Minis∣try. See 1 Tim. 1.12. And I thank CHRIST JESUS our LORD, who hath enabled me; for that he counted me faithful, putting me into the Ministry.

His Knowledge of the Hearts of Men qualifies him to judge infallibly of Men, and to make a most wise and just Choice. The righteous Lord trieth the Hearts and Reins. (Psal. 7.9.) Since He knows the Hearts of all Men, He cannot be deceived: but is able to make the most righteous Judgment, and give a perfect Lot. His Eyes are upon the righteous; He
beholdeth every Peter, that can appeal to Him, say∣ing, Lord, thou knowest all things, thou knowest that I love Thee: And unto such an one He saith, Feed my SheepJoh. 21.17..

His Knowledge of the Hearts of Men argues his Ability to prepare and dispose Men's Hearts aright: And if he does not find them at present fit for his purpose (as in the Case of Saul, who from a Blasphemer and Persecutor, was chang'd into a Preacher and Apostle of JESUS CHRIST) he has power to enable them1 Tim. 1.12., to furnish and spirit them to their Work. He can give them another Heart, as in the case of the for∣mer Saul, the famous Son of Kish1 Sam. 10.6, 9.. Behold, a Com∣pany of Prophets met him, after he was anointed by Samuel, and the Spirit of GOD came upon him, and he prophesy'd among them, and was turned into ano∣ther Man. And it became a Proverb in Israel, Is Saul also among the Prophets! — So true are those Obser∣vations of the Wise Man, The King's heart is in the hand of the Lord, as the rivers of Water, He turneth it whithersoever He willPro. 20.1.. — The Preparations of the heart in Man, and the answer of the Tongue, are from the LordCh. 16.1.. He has all Hearts in his Hand, as well as under his Eye. He fashioneth Men's Hearts, and worketh in them to will and to do of his good plea∣sure. Unto every one of us is given Grace accord∣ing to the measure of the Gift of CHRIST. He can easi∣ly inspire a Man with Divine Principles, and heaven∣ly Tempers: can fill him with Knowledge and put Wisdom in his Heart, that he may go out and come in before his People. The LORD is able to make all Grace abound towards him; to give him largeness of Heart, and Wisdom exceeding much. — Hence then, supposing in the case before us, the Lot should fall upon a Person, whom some may apprehend less
accomplish'd, and less worthy: yet consider that the Lord knoweth and influenceth the Hearts of all Men, and can prepare his Heart to the Work he is call'd unto, and let this suppress every anxious Passion or unbelieving Thought; still our Complaints, and open our Hearts to lay out Faith and Prayer for him.

In a word, Consider, He who searcheth the Reins, can govern your Hearts, as he pleaseth, and can unite you in your Judgments and Inclinations, The hand of GOD may be to give you one Heart. So that you shall be perfectly joined together in the same Mind, and with one Mouth glorify GOD, in the unanimous Choice of some meet and worthy Person. Or if he shou'd permit you to be somewhat divided in your Apprehensions, He can prevent the Disagreement from passing over to the Affections, and still keep your Hearts knit together in Love. Or if any (which GOD prevent) shou'd be irregularly dispos'd after the Matter is reduc'd to a fair Issue, He that sitteth in the Heavens, and that knows the Thoughts of the Wise, can restrain and over-rule, to his own Glory.

All which Reflections tend to strengthen Faith and Hope. Wherefore let not your Heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid. Trust in the Lord at all times, O ye People, pour out your Desires before Him; and in the way of Duty leave the Affair and all Events with Him. In cases of Difficulty, which depend very much upon the Hearts of Men, as well as in all others, we shou'd chearfully refer the Ad∣ministration and Success of our Concernments unto Him, in whose hand the Righteous, and the Wise, and their Works are, and whose are all our Ways; not anx∣iously perplex our selves, about the Events of un∣certain Futurity, but perswading our selves that the Lord will do better for us than our own Counsel and Choice, be resign'd to his good Pleasure. And when He by his Providence declares his Will (as
one Dr. Tillotson. Vol. II. page 636. observes) look upon it as the Sentence of a wise and just Judge, in which all Parties concern'd ought to acquiesce and rest fully satisfy'd. We cannot but be convinced, that this is very reasona∣ble, to leave the management of things to Him, whose Understanding is infinite, and therefore knows best how to order them. The Government of the World is a very curious and complicated thing, and not to be tamper'd with by every unskilful hand: and therefore as an unskilful Man, after he has tamper'd a great while with a Watch, thinking to bring it into better Order, and is at last convinced that he can do no good upon it, carries it to him that made it, to mend and put it in Order; so must we do, after all our Care and Anxiety about our own private Concernments, or the publick State of Things: we must give over governing the World, as a Business past our Skill, as a Province too hard, and a Knowledge too won∣derful for us, and leave it to him who made the World, to govern it and take Care of it. And if we be not thus affected and disposed, we do not believe the Providence of GOD, whatever Profes∣sion we make of it; or are not firmly persuaded of the Wisdom and Goodness of it.

3. The Consideration of CHRIST, as knowing the Hearts of all Men, will have a further Influence, to promote a Care of Integrity, in the whole Conduct of the Affair before us; and to comfort us by a Sense of our Sincerity, both under the Crosses of Provi∣dence, and the Calumnies of Men.

This Reflection duly entertained, will be a Motive and Help to Sincerity: will tend to rectify our Aims; to make us keep our Hearts with all Diligence, and study to shew our selves approved unto Him, who
trieth the Reins. That is Christian's Motto, 1 Thes. 2.4. Not as pleasing Men, but GOD which trieth our Hearts.

It will be a good Preservative and Guard against the Rashness and Folly, which is too often committed in this Affair, when the LORD JESUS CHRIST is left out of our Schemes, or we leave to him only the Ex∣ecution of our Decrees, and mock him by commend∣ing to his Benediction, what we have projected with∣out his Counsel.

It will promote Sincerity in our Desires and Prayers, that CHRIST wou'd shew us whom He hath chosen: and therefore will make us beware that no Idol of Jealousy have harbour in our Bosoms; which will provoke the Lord to pass that Doom upon us, Ezek. 14. These Men have set up their Idols in their Heart;—should I at all be inquired of by them? — Surely I the LORD will answer them by my self, and will set my Face against them. — The Scripture has put those solemn Words of prayer into our Mouths, 1 Kin. 8.39. Then hear thou in Heaven thy Dwelling place, and give to every one according to his Ways, whose Heart Thou knowest. But how shall we dare to pray in such awful Language, without a most sollicitous Care to avoid Hypocrisy; and to seek the Lord with our whole Desire, lifting up holy Hands, and drawing nigh to Him with a true Heart: Whose penetrating Eye has an immediate Access to the Mind, and a distict Prospect of all the se∣cret Motions in every Breast, through all possible Masks and Disguises!

Moreover, If we are under the power of this ap∣prehension, that his Eye is upon us, by whom Actions are weigh'd, and who understandeth our Thoughts afar off; it will excite a Care of Uprightness in our Choice and whole Management. That is propos'd as a Motive to Sincerity and Care to please the Lord: Prov. 21.2. Every way of a Man is right in his own Eyes: but the Lord pondereth the Hearts. Hence
David strongly recommends it to his Son 1 Chro. 28.9. Serve him with a perfect heart, and with a willing mind; for the Lord searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts. This Reflection had an excellent Influence on holy David himself, 1 Chro. 29.17. I know, my GOD, that thou triest the heart, and hast pleasure in Uprightness. As for me (therefore) in the Uprightness of my heart I have willingly offer'd all these things. The Sense of this will be a powerful Excitement to do what we do, heartily, as to the Lord, and not to Men; to act with an upright View to his Glory, as our ultimate Aim, and to propose no other Ends but what as subordinate to this, He will ap∣prove of. The Sense of his Heart-searching Eye upon us will make us abhor vain Thoughts and wic∣ked Purposes, as an Abomination to the Lord; and put us upon purifying our Aims from all base alloy of Prejudice, Interest, or any other impure tincture. It will antidote and fortify us against all manner of Temptations to Evil, by the Principles of Shame and Fear. The People of GOD found it a happy Re∣straint to them: Psal. 44.18 — 21. Our Heart is not turned back, neither have our steps declined from thy way. — If we have forgotten the Name of our GOD; shall not GOD search this out? For He knoweth the Se∣crets of the Heart. — This is improveable as a strong Caution against all criminal Partiality. Hence the Apostle exhorting Timothy to be impartial and up∣right in his Conduct, addresses him after that solemn Manner, 1 Tim. 5.21, 22. I charge thee before GOD, and the Lord JESUS CHRIST, and the elect Angels, that thou observe these things, without preferring one be∣fore another [or without Prejudice, as the Original properly signifies, and the vulgar Latin translates it] doing nothing by partiality: Lay hands suddenly on no Man, neither be partakers of othea Men's Sins.

Thus a Sense of the Eye of CHRIST upon us tends to
make us beware of Partiality and Hypocrisy: and that Consideration receives additional force from the prospect of a future Judgment. For this Knowlege and critical Observation of Men's Hearts and Ways, is in order to a day of reckoning. (Jer. 17.10. and Prov. 24.12.) And the serious Consideration of our being all to appear before the Judgment Seat of CHRIST, tends to make us labour, that we may be accepted of Him. Such Influence it had on the Apostle, 2 Cor. 5.9, 10. Hence our LORD said to his Disciples, Luk. 12.1, 2. Beware ye of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is Hypocrisy. For there is nothing covered, that shall not be revealed; neither hid, that shall not be known. A due Sense of our Accountableness to the LORD JE∣SUS CHRIST will awe and restrain us from Sin, and excite us unto Duty: will make us ponder our Ways, and look well to our Goings, that we may be in Be∣haviour as becometh Holiness; doing nothing in any Affair, but what will bear the Light; and so may have this for our Rejoycing, the testimony of our Conscience —. Then shall we have Confidence to∣ward GOD: Whereas if our Heart condemn us, the Lord is greater than our Heart and knoweth all things. He will bring every Work into Judgment, with every secret thing. Then the Thoughts of Men's Hearts shall be reveal'd: Whatsoever ye have spo∣ken in Darkness, shall be heard in the Light; and that which you have spoken in the Ear in Closets, shall be proclaimed upon the House-tops. The good Works of some are manifest before-hand, and they that are otherwise, cannot be hid. And hence the Conscience of Integrity will give us a prospect of our having boldness in the Day of Judgment, and Confidence before the Son of Man at his appearing.

A Sense of Sincerity will give us a holy boldness now, and Access with Confidence unto the Lord in Prayer: will embolden us to wrestle with Him for the
Blessing, unto whom we may with the utmost Security commit every good Cause. Prov. 16.2, 3. The Lord weigheth the Spirits: Commit thy Works to the Lord, and thy Thoughts shall be established.

And it will minister to our Consolation under any Disappointment we may meet with, if we can appeal to the Searcher of Hearts, as witness to our Sincerity. Psal. 142.2. When my spirit was overwhelmed within me, then thou knewest my Path. Yea, if the Lot of any be involuntarily cast under an unfaithful Ministry, and they have born due Testimony against the same, it may be consolatory to them to think that CHRIST knows their Works and their Patience, and how they can∣not bear them which are evil, and have tried them which say they are Apostles and are not. (See Rev. 2.2.)

So under invidious Characters, hard Speeches and Reproaches of Men, who may tax us with Partiality, carnal Policy, secret Intreagues and fraudulent Prac∣tices, or with sinister Respects, and unjust Prejudices, or the like; here a View to the future Account, and the Thought of CHRIST's all-seeing Eye, may sup∣port and comfort us, if we are really conscious to our Integrity and Innocence. We may appeal to Hea∣ven, and say as the Prophet (Jer. 20.12.) O Lord of Hosts, that triest the Righteous, and seest the Reins and Heart, — unto Thee have I opened my Cause. We may humbly hope that GOD which knoweth the Hearts, will bear us Witness. (Acts 15.8.) And may learn to despise the uncharitable Censures of Men, when they speak Evil of the things which they know not. Hence that of the Apostle, 1 Cor. 4. — It is required in Stewards, that a Man be found faithful. But with me it is a VERY SMALL thing that I should be judged of you, or of Man's Judgment. But he that judgeth is the Lord. Therefore judge nothing before the Time, until the Lord come, who will bring to Light the hidden things of Darkness, and will make manifest
the Counsels of the Heart: And then shall every man have Praise of GOD; every Man who has walked in his Uprightness.

In a word, The thought of CHRIST's Inspection of us, and our Accountableness to Him, will tend to prevent all unchristian Heats and Animosities; to allay and hush Men's Passions, so apt to be unquiet and impetuous, when cross'd in their particular Views. It will teach us all to watch against uncharitable Thoughts, and evil Surmisings, contrary to the Love which shou'd be among Brethren: and will teach us to take heed to our Ways, that we offend not with our Tongues: will teach us to forbear all Clamour, and Wrath, and Evil-speaking, Impatience, unreaso∣nable Humour, and Self-willedness: And on the contrary will teach us to deny our selves, to be kind∣ly affectioned one to another with brotherly Love, in honour preferring one another, being swift to hear, slow to speak: Not to mind high things, but to con∣descend unto Men of low Estate, and every one please his Neighbour for his Good, to Edification: To be of a yielding Temper, studying to be quiet; and if it be possible, as much as lieth in us, endea∣vouring to live peaceably. To this End is that Ex∣hortation, Col. 4.6. Let your Speech be alway with grace, seasoned with Salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every Man. And hence those Intreaties, Phil. 4.1, 2, 5. Therefore my Brethren, dearly beloved, and longed for, my Joy and Crown, so stand fast my dearly beloved. I beseech Euodias, and beseech Syntiche, that they be of the same Mind in the LORD. — Let your Moderation be known to all Men. THE LORD IS AT HAND. And agreeable are those Counsels of the Apostle James: My Brethren have not the Faith of our LORD JESUS CHRIST, the LORD of Glory, with Respect of Persons. — So speak ye, and so do, as they that shall be judged by the Law of Liberty. — My Brethren be
not many Masters; knowing that ye shall receive the greater Condemnation. — Do ye think that the Scrip∣ture saith in vain. The Spirit that dwelleth in us lusteth to Envy? But submit your selves to GOD: Resist the Devil; and grudge not one against another, Bre∣thren, lest ye be condemned: Behold, the Judge stand∣eth before the Door.
I conclude with those Apostical Benedictions and Apologies, in Rom. 15.

Now the GOD of Patience and Consolation grant that you be like-minded one towards another, accord∣ing to CHRIST JESUS. That ye may with one Mind and one Mouth glorify GOD. — The GOD of Hope fill you with all Joy and Peace in believing, that ye may abound in Hope through the power of the HOLY GHOST. And I my self am persuaded of you, my Bre∣thren, that ye are full of Goodness, filled with all Knowledge, able also to admonish one another. Ne∣vertheless, Brethren, I have written the more boldly unto you, in some sort, as putting you in Mind; be∣cause of the Grace that is given me of GOD, that I should be the Minister of JESUS CHRIST unto you. Now therefore I beseech you, Brethren, for the LORD JESUS CHRIST's sake, & for the Love of the Spirit, that ye strive together with me in Prayers to GOD for me, that I may with you be refreshed. And now the GOD of Peace be with you all. Amen.
